Chem. 1994; 269: 19796-19802Google Scholar), with the modifications outlined under âMaterials and Methods.â As shown previously for a GST fusion protein containing the first 246 amino acids of p115 RhoGEF (26Kozasa T. Jiang X. Hart M.J. Sternweis P.M. Singer W.D. Gilman A.G. Bollag G. Sternweis P.C. Science. 1998; 280: 2109-2111Google Scholar), the p115 rgRGS (aa 1â252) stimulated the GTPase activity of GÎ±13 as well as the full-length exchange factor (Fig.3B). However, a protein with further truncation at its C terminus, p115 rgRGS (aa 1â215), was a less effective stimulator of the GTPase activity of GÎ±13. Removal of additional C-terminal residues resulted in unstable proteins that had no detectable stimulation of the GTPase activity of GÎ±13 (data not shown). The effects of N-terminal deletion are shown in Fig. 3(CâF). Removal of the first 5 or 12 N-terminal amino acids, p115 rgRGS (aa 6â252) or p115 rgRGS (aa 13â252), respectively, did not alter GAP activities toward GÎ±13 (Fig.3C). Removal of the first 17 or 21 N-terminal amino acids did not allow expression of protein domains as discussed previously. P115 rgRGS (aa 25â252) was expressed modestly as a viable domain. Although an active GAP, the potency of this construct was only about 0.1% that of the full-length rgRGS domain encoded within aa 1â252 (Fig. 3, DâF). Finally, deletion of the N terminus up to the predicted RGS box, p115 RhoGEF (aa 42â252), produced a fragment that expressed well (see above). Despite binding strongly to GÎ±13 (about 10â20% as well as p115 rgRGS (aa 1â252), see Fig. 2B), this fragment had essentially no GAP activity toward GÎ±13 (Fig. 3, CâE). The hint of activity observed at 10 Î¼m (Fig. 3E) is similar to nonspecific effects of adding other control proteins and is not increased at higher concentrations of p115 rgRGS (aa 42â252). GTRAP48 has been shown to bind to GÎ±13 (25Jackson M. Song W. Liu M.Y. Jin L. Dykes-Hoberg M. Lin C.I. Bowers W.J. Federoff H.J. Sternweis P.C. Rothstein J.D. Nature. 2001; 410: 89-93Google Scholar), but the functional consequences and potential interaction with GÎ±12 are unknown. The domain arrangements of GTRAP48 and p115 RhoGEF are compared in Fig.4A, and schematic descriptions of various constructs are shown. In a chimeric protein, N48C115, the N-terminal rgRGS region of p115 RhoGEF is replaced with the homologous region from GTRAP48. Examples of purified proteins that were expressed via these constructs with EE or GST tags are shown in Fig.4B. The ability of GTRAP48 to bind to GÎ±12 as well as GÎ±13 was assessed by immunoprecipitation after transient expression in COS cells. COS cells were transfected with either myc-tagged GTRAP48 or myc-tagged p115 RhoGEF and either constitutively active GÎ±13 (Q226L) or constitutively active GÎ±12 (Q229L). Both p115 RhoGEF and GTRAP48 bound to GÎ±13 in the presence of AlF 4â. Although p115 RhoGEF also bound well to GÎ±12, the interaction of this Î± subunit with GTRAP48 is apparently weaker and was hard to detect (Fig.5A, see âDiscussionâ). The dependence of association of these GTPase-deficient forms of GÎ±12 and GÎ±13 on AlF 4â may seem surprising. However, this reflects both the multiple states of the Î± subunits upon lysis of cells in GDP and slow conversion of GÎ±Â·GTP to GÎ±Â·GDP through slow hydrolysis or nucleotide exchange over the extensive timeframe required for the immunoprecipitation. To define the regions in GTRAP48 responsible for binding GÎ±13, two segments, which included sequences homologous to the rgRGS domain of p115 RhoGEF, were expressed and examined. The first segment encodes aa 1â539, which includes the PDZ-and proline-rich domains that precede the rgRGS domain (Fig. 4). The second construct encodes aa 285â495, which contains amino acids homologous to the N-terminal region of p115 RhoGEF (Fig. 4). Both constructs of GTRAP48 were found to preferentially bind the activated form of GÎ±13 (Fig. 5B). The relative affinities of GTRAP48, a fragment of GTRAP48 (aa 289â539), and p115 RhoGEF for GÎ±13 were assessed by competitive binding with immobilized GST-tagged p115 rgRGS aa (1) (Fig. 5C). Purified full-length p115 RhoGEF and HIS-tagged p115 rgRGS (aa 1â252) effectively attenuated binding of activated GÎ±13 to the immobilized p115 rgRGS at stoichiometries of 5- to 10-fold over the immobilized domain. In contrast, EE-tagged GTRAP48 or its HIS-tagged rgRGS domain, GTRAP48 (aa 289â539), at concentrations of 5- to 10-fold over the GST-tagged p115 rgRGS (aa 1â252) showed little competition for binding to GÎ±13. Thus, although the GTRAP48 rgRGS domain bound GÎ±13, it did so with a definitively lower affinity than the p115 rgRGS domain. The ability of GTRAP48 to stimulate the GTPase activity of GÎ±13 in a single-turnover assay is shown in Fig.6A. Both GTRAP48 and N48C115 (a chimera derived from GTRAP48 and p115 RhoGEF; Fig. 4A) displayed low but significant stimulation of the GTPase activity of GÎ±13. However, their activities were substantially less than the stimulation obtained with an equivalent amount of p115 RhoGEF. The N-terminal fragments of GTRAP48, which contain its rgRGS domain, failed to stimulate the GTPase activity of GÎ±13 at the concentrations tested (Fig. 6B). Factor VIII binds to phospholipid membranes and to von Willebrand factor (vWf) via its second C domain, which has lectin homology. The crystal structure of the C2 domain has prompted a model in which membrane binding is mediated by two hydrophobic spikes, each composed of a pair of residues displayed on a Î²-hairpin turn, and also by net positive charge and specific interactions with phospho-l-serine. To test this model, we prepared 16 factor VIII mutants in which single or multiple amino acids were changed to alanine. Mutants at Arg2215, Arg2220, Lys2227, Lys2249, Gln2213, Asn2217, and Phe2196/Thr2197 had specific activities that were >70% of the wild type. Mutants at Arg2209, Lys2227, Trp2313, and Arg2320 were degraded within the cell. Hydrophobic spike mutants at Met2199/Phe2200, Leu2251/Leu2252, and Met2199/Phe2200/Leu2251/Leu2252(4-Ala) exhibited 43, 59, and 91% reduction in specific activity in the activated partial thromboplastin time assay. In a phospholipid-limiting factor Xa activation assay, these mutants had a 65, 85, and 96% reduction in specific activity. Equilibrium binding of fluorescent, sonicated phospholipid vesicles to mutants immobilized on Superose beads was measured by flow cytometry. The affinities for phospholipid were reduced â¼20-, 30-, and >35-fold for 2199/2200, 2251/2252, and 4-Ala, respectively. A dimeric form of mature vWf bound to immobilized factor VIII and the same mutants, but the affinities of the mutants were reduced â¼5-, 10-, and >20-fold, respectively. In a competition, solution phase enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, plasma vWf bound factor VIII and the same mutants with the affinities for the mutants reduced >5-, >5-, and >50-fold, respectively. We conclude that the two hydrophobic spikes are constituents of both the phospholipid-binding and vWf-binding motifs. In plasma, vWf apparently binds the inherently sticky membrane-binding motif, preventing nonspecific interactions. The membrane-bound factor VIIIa-factor IXa complex cleaves the zymogen, factor X, to factor Xa, which is then responsible for catalyzing prothrombin activation (5Mann K.G. Nesheim M.E. Church W.R. Haley P. Krishnaswamy S. Blood. 1990; 76: 1-16Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The importance of this enzyme complex is illustrated by hemophilia, a disease in which a deficiency of either factor VIII (hemophilia A) or factor IX (hemophilia B) leads to life-threatening bleeding. Rosing J. Hemker H. J. Biol. Chem. 1981; 256: 3433-3442Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Chem. 1996; 271: 11120-11125Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (85) Google Scholar). These membranes also increase the affinity of factor IXa for factor VIIIa and for factor X. The proteins share a repeating domain structure of A1-A2-B-A3-C1-C2 in which the A domains are homologous with ceruloplasmin, the B domain is unique to each protein, and the C domains are homologous with discoidin I, a phospholipid-binding lectin (14Bartles J. Galvin N. Frazier W. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1982; 687: 129-136Crossref Scopus (13) Google Scholar), and with a murine milk fat globule membrane protein (15Stubbs J. Lekutis C. Singer K. Bui A. Yuzuki D. Srinivasan U. Parry G. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 8417-8421Crossref PubMed Scopus (263) Google Scholar). Both factor VIII and factor V bind with high affinity to phospholipid membranes via the âlight chainâ composed of the A3-C1-C2 segment (16Krishnaswamy S. Mann K. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 5714-5723Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). However, factor VIII requires more PS per binding site than factor V (13Gilbert G.E. Furie B.C. Furie B. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 815-822Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), and current evidence implicates different domains in membrane binding. While binding of factor V is apparently mediated by both the A3 domain (17Kalafatis M. Jenny R.J. Mann K.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 21580-21589Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and the C2 domain (18Ortel T. Devore-Carter D. Quinn-Allen M. Kane W. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 4189-4198Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and is influenced by glycosylation within the C2 domain (19Kim S.W. Ortel T.L. Quinn-Allen M.A. Yoo L. Worfolk L. Xhai X. Lentz B.R. Kane W.H. Biochemisty. 1999; 38: 11448-11454Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar), binding of factor VIII is apparently mediated by the C2 domain (20Arai M. Scandella D. Hoyer L. J. Clin. Invest. 1989; 83: 1978-1984Crossref PubMed Scopus (150) Google Scholar, 21Foster P.A. Fulcher C.A. Houghten R.A. Zimmerman T.S. Blood. 1990; 75: 1999-2004Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) and is independent of glycosylation. Recent publication of two crystal structures for the C2 domain of factor V (22Macedo-Ribeiro S. Bode W. Huber R. Quinn-Allen M.A. Kim S.W. Ortel T.L. Bourenkov G.P. Bartunik H.D. Stubbs M.T. Kane W.H. Fuentes-Prior P. Nature. 1999; 402: 434-439Crossref PubMed Scopus (223) Google Scholar) and a single structure for the C2 domain of factor VIII (23Pratt K.P. Shen B.W. Takeshima K. Davie E.W. Fujikawa K. Stoddard B.L. Nature. 1999; 402: 439-442Crossref PubMed Scopus (285) Google Scholar) has provided the basis for a model membrane-binding mechanism. Both C2 domains display two hydrophobic spikes at the tips of protruding Î²-hairpin turns. These hydrophobic spikes are hypothesized to penetrate the hydrophobic core of a phospholipid bilayer. Hydrophilic residues above the hydrophobic spikes are hypothesized to form specific hydrogen bonds and salt bridges that recognize the phospho-l-serine motif of PS. Site-directed mutagenesis studies of factor V have confirmed that the first hydrophobic spike, composed of Trp2063/Trp2064, has a lower affinity for phospholipid and a corresponding decrease in function in the prothrombinase complex when the residues are replaced by Ala/Ala (24Kim S.W. Quinn-Allen M.A. Camp J.T. Macedo-Ribeiro S. Fuentes-Prior P. Bode W. Kane W.H. Biochemistry. 2000; 39: 1951-1958Crossref PubMed Scopus (66) Google Scholar). In this study, we have tested the parallel model of factor VIII binding to phospholipid membranes by performing functional studies on factor VIII in which many of the proposed membrane-binding residues have been altered by site-directed mutagenesis. In plasma, factor VIII differs from factor V in that it circulates in a noncovalent complex with von Willebrand factor (vWf) (25Lollar P. Mayo Clin. Proc. 1991; 66: 524-534Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar). vWf competitively inhibits factor VIII from binding to PS-containing membranes (26Andersson L. Brown J. Biochem. J. 1981; 200: 161-167Crossref PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar, 27Gilbert G.E. Drinkwater D. Barter S. Clouse S.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 15861-15868Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and to activated platelets (28Nesheim M. Pittman D. Giles A. Fass D. Wang J. Slonosky D. Kaufman R. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 17815-17820Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Proteolytic activation by thrombin removes an acidic amino acid-rich region from the amino terminus of the light chain, thereby reducing the affinity for vWf (29Foster P. Fulcher C. Houghten R. Zimmerman T. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 5230-5234Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 30Pittman D. Kaufman R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1988; 85: 2429-2433Crossref PubMed Scopus (142) Google Scholar). Subsequently, the two proteins dissociate to allow factor VIII to bind to activated platelets (28Nesheim M. Pittman D. Giles A. Fass D. Wang J. Slonosky D. Kaufman R. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 17815-17820Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and to PS-containing membranes (27Gilbert G.E. Drinkwater D. Barter S. Clouse S.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 15861-15868Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Several monoclonal antibodies to the C2 domain of factor VIII inhibit both binding of factor VIII to vWf and binding to phospholipid membranes. These data suggest that there is substantial overlap between the phospholipid-binding and the vWf-binding motifs of the factor VIII C2 domain. Thus, it is logical to test any factor VIII C2 mutants with decreased phospholipid affinity to determine whether the vWf binding affinity is also decreased. The total volume of Superose for each column was 10 Î¼l, and the column was prepared by injecting the medium into 0.02-inch internal diameter tubing where the column formed above a 10-Î¼m frit (Alltech). After 30 min, the samples were diluted to 500 Î¼l in the same buffer within 30 s of reading the fluorescence/microsphere by flow cytometry with a Becton Dickinson FacScan within 30 s of dilution. Data were acquired with all channels in log mode, and binding data were analyzed as the geometric mean fluorescence/microsphere. Microspheres were detected and distinguished from background noise based upon the characteristic forward and side light scatter characteristics. Binding data were analyzed using the equation, F=F0+Fmax(PL/(KD+PL))+PLÃkf(1)Equation 1 where F is the measured fluorescence/Superose bead, F 0 is the fluorescence for Superose bead in the absence of NBD-labeled vesicles, F max is the maximum fluorescence with saturating concentrations of NBD-labeled vesicles, and K D is the dissociation constant for phospholipid (PL) binding to factor VIII. The termk f is the measured fluorescence per concentration unit of free phospholipid vesicles due to unbound phospholipid and any nonspecific binding of phospholipid vesicles to control Superose beads lacking factor VIII. The variable K D was determined using nonlinear least squares analysis with the software Graphpad Prism 3.0. Subsequently, the mixtures of factor VIII with vWf were placed in microtiter wells coated with antibody ESH4. vWf competes for the ESH4 epitope so that only free factor VIII was available to bind to immobilized ESH4. These conditions were chosen so that the assay results would report the equilibrium affinity of mutants and wild type factor VIII for vWf. After 1 h of incubation, the wells were washed thoroughly, and bound factor VIII was detected with antibody ESH8, followed by horseradish peroxidase-conjugated goat anti-mouse antibody. The wells were developed with p-nitophenyl phosphate reagent (Sigma). The competition binding data were interpreted as binding data by assuming that all factor VIII that was not bound to ESH4 was bound to vWf and that binding to vWf was an equilibrium binding process. The ELISA data were subtracted from a constant value equivalent to the maximum colorimetric intensity to generate upright binding curves. The data from two experiments were combined, and the combined curves were fitted by nonlinear, least squares analysis using Graphpad Prism 3.0 software on a Macintosh computer. The CD11/CD18 (Î²2) integrins are leukocyte-specific adhesion receptors, and their ability to bind ligands on other cells can be activated by extracellular stimuli. During cell activation, the CD18 chain is known to become phosphorylated on serine and functionally important threonine residues located in the intracellular C-terminal tail. Here, we identify catalytic domain fragments of protein kinase C (PKC) Î´ and PKCÎ²I/II as the major protein kinases in leukocyte extracts that phosphorylate a peptide corresponding to the cytoplasmic tail of the integrin CD18 chain. The sites phosphorylated in vitro were identified as Ser-745 and Thr-758. PKCÎ± and PKCÎ· also phosphorylated these residues, and PKCÎ± additionally phosphorylated Thr-760. Ser-745, a novel site, was shown to become phosphorylated in T cells in response to phorbol ester stimulation. Ser-756, a residue not phosphorylated by PKC isoforms, also became phosphorylated in T cells after phorbol ester stimulation. When leukocyte extracts were subjected to affinity chromatography on agarose to which residues 751â761 of the CD18 chain phosphorylated at Thr-758 were bound covalently, the only proteins that bound specifically were identified as isoforms of 14-3-3 proteins. Thus, PKC-mediated phosphorylation of CD18 after cell stimulation could lead to the recruitment of 14-3-3 proteins to the activated integrin, which may play a role in regulating its adhesive state or ability to signal. Immunol. 1990; 144: 191-197PubMed Google Scholar) and Thr (25Valmu L. Gahmberg C.G. J. Immunol. 1995; 155: 1175-1183PubMed Google Scholar) residues. Thr phosphorylation is more transient than Ser phosphorylation. The Thr phosphorylation may regulate the adhesive state of the integrin, because mutation of three consecutive threonines in the integrin chain (Thr-758, Thr-759, and Thr-760) reduce integrin binding to ICAM-1 (29Hibbs M.L. Jakes S. Stacker S.A. Wallace R.W. Springer T.A. J. Exp. Med. 1991; 174: 1227-1238Crossref PubMed Scopus (210) Google Scholar) and cytoskeletal association (16Peter K. Toole T.E. J. Exp. Med. 1995; 181: 315-326Crossref PubMed Scopus (145) Google Scholar) of the integrin molecules. Additionally, phosphorylated integrin molecules preferentially partition with the actin cytoskeleton (33Valmu L. Fagerholm S. Suila H. Gahmberg C.G. Eur. J. Immunol. 1999; 29: 2107-2118Crossref PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar), indicating that phosphorylation of integrins could regulate integrin-cytoskeleton interactions. In addition to their adhesive properties, the integrins are also involved in activating intracellular signaling pathways and can thus mediate bi-directional signaling across the plasma membrane. In fibroblasts they form focal adhesion complexes with cytoskeletal elements and a wide range of signaling molecules (34Schoenwaelder S. Burridge K. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 1999; 11: 274-286Crossref PubMed Scopus (647) Google Scholar). In leukocytes these signaling complexes are believed to be more transient, because leukocytes are involved in relatively short lived interactions with other cells. Several cytoskeletal and signaling molecules have been shown to interact with the CD18 cytoplasmic tail, including the actin-binding proteins talin (33Valmu L. Fagerholm S. Suila H. Gahmberg C.G. Eur. J. Immunol. 1999; 29: 2107-2118Crossref PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar, 35Kupfer A. Burn P. Singer S.J. J. Mol. Cell. Immunol. 1990; 4: 317-325PubMed Google Scholar), filamin (36Sharma C.P Ezzell R.M. Arnaout M.A. J. Immunol. 1995; 154: 3461-3470PubMed Google Scholar), and Î±-actinin (37Pavalko F.M. LaRoche S.M. J. Immunol. 1993; 151: 3795-3807PubMed Google Scholar, 38Sampath R. Gallagher P.J. Pavalko F.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 33588-33594Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (197) Google Scholar), the adaptor proteins Rack1 (receptor for activated PKC) (39Lilientahl J. Chang D.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 2379-2383Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (300) Google Scholar) and cytohesin (40Kolanus W. Nagel W. Shiller B. Zeitlmann L. Godar S. Stockinger H. Seed B. Cell. 1996; 86: 233-242Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (401) Google Scholar), and the transcription factor Jun activation domain-binding protein (41Bianchi E. Denti S. Granata A. Bossi G. Geginat J. Villa A. Rogge L. Pardi R. Nature. 2000; 404: 617-621Crossref PubMed Scopus (184) Google Scholar). In this study, we present evidence that PKC isoforms are the major protein kinases that phosphorylate the C terminus of the integrin CD18 chain in leukocytes. Ser-745 is identified as a novel phosphorylation site in the integrin cytoplasmic domain. Additionally, we show that a Thr-758-phosphorylated integrin peptide can interact with 14-3-3 proteins in leukocyte lysates and thus potentially initiate signaling complex formation âdownstreamâ of the phosphorylated integrin molecules. Protein kinases were assayed using a peptide corresponding to the integrin CD18 C terminus (RRFEK EKLKS QWNND NPLFK SATTT VMNPK FAES). Recombinant PKC isoforms and activity eluting from column fractions were measured at 30 Â°C in an assay containing 50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 0.1 mm EGTA, 100 Î¼g/ml peptide, 2.5 Î¼m PKI, 10 mmmagnesium acetate, 0.1 mm [Î³-32P]ATP (106 cpm/nmol). One unit of activity was that amount that catalyzed the incorporation of 1 nmol of phosphate into the synthetic peptide in 1 min. Human leukocytes were isolated from buffy coat pools by centrifuging for 20 min at 1500 Ã g. The leukocyte layer was then subjected to Ficoll gradient centrifugation and washed with phosphate-buffered saline. The cells were lysed in 50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 1 mm EDTA, 1 mm EGTA, 1% Triton X-100, 1 mm sodium orthovanadate, 10 mm sodium glycerophosphate, 50 mm NaF, 5 mm sodium pyrophosphate, 0.27m sucrose, 2 Î¼m microcystin, 0.1% 2-mercaptoethanol, 1 mm benzamidine, and protease inhibitor mixture. The lysates were frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored in aliquots at â80 Â°C. The lysates (12 g of protein) were fractionated from 10 to 20% polyethylene glycol 6000 (PEG). After stirring for 3 h at 4 Â°C, the 20% PEG suspension was centrifuged for 30 min at 7000 Ã g, the supernatant discarded, and the pellet redissolved in 50 ml of buffer A (50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 0.1 mm EGTA, 0.1% (v/v) 2-mercaptoethanol, 5% (v/v) glycerol, 0.03% (w/v) Brij 35). The solution was applied to a 5-ml Hitrap Q column equilibrated in buffer A. After washing with equilibration buffer, the column was developed with a linear salt gradient to 0.7 m NaCl in the same buffer. One major peak of activity was detected eluting at 0.3â0.4 m NaCl, which was pooled, diluted 5-fold in buffer B (50 mm BisTris, pH 6.5, 5% (v/v) glycerol, 0.1% (v/v) 2-mercaptoethanol, 1 mm EGTA, 0.03% (w/v) Brij 35), and applied to a 1-ml Hitrap heparin column equilibrated in buffer B. After washing until no protein could be detected in the eluate, the column was developed with a linear salt gradient to 1 m NaCl. One major peak of activity was detected, eluting at 0.2 m NaCl. This was pooled, diluted in buffer B, and applied to a 1-ml MonoQ column, which was developed with a linear salt gradient to 0.7 m NaCl. The most active fractions, eluting at 0.3 m NaCl were pooled, diluted with buffer C (50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.7, 0.1 mm EGTA, 0.1% (v/v) 2-mercaptoethanol, 5% (v/v) glycerol, 0.03% (w/v) Brij 35), and applied to a 1-ml MonoQ column, which was developed with a linear salt gradient to 1 m NaCl. The most active fractions, eluting at 0.3 m NaCl were pooled, concentrated to 25 Î¼l with Vivaspin columns, and subjected to gel filtration on Superdex 200 (30 Ã 0.32 cm) equilibrated in buffer A plus 0.15 m NaCl. Fractions of 50 Î¼l were collected. The flow-through from the Hitrap-heparin column was chromatographed successively on 1-ml MonoQ columns equilibrated in buffer B and buffer C, respectively, as described above. A single major activity peak was detected eluting at 0.3 m NaCl in buffer B and 0.35m in buffer C. The activity was then chromatographed on a 2-ml protamine-agarose column equilibrated in buffer A. The column was washed with 5 ml of buffer A plus 200 mm NaCl and then with buffer A plus 1 m NaCl. Four fractions, each of 6 ml, were collected. Proteins of interest were excised from SDS-polyacrylamide gels, digested with trypsin, and identified using a Perspective Biosystems (Framingham, MA) Elite STR matrix-assisted laser desorption-time of flight-mass spectrometer as described previously (46Woods L.Y. Rena G. Morrice N. Barthel A. Becker W. Guo S. Unterman T.G. Cohen P. Biochem. J. 2001; 355: 597-607Crossref PubMed Scopus (217) Google Scholar). Phosphoamino acid analysis of integrin CD18 C terminus was also performed as described (47Lawler S. Fleming Y. Goedert M. Cohen P. Curr. Biol. 1998; 8: 1387-1390Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Integrins were affinity-purified from human leukocytes using R7E4 columns as described previously (48Kantor C. Suomalainen-Nevanlinna H. Patarroyo M. Osterlund K. Bergman T. Jornvall H. Schroder J. Gahmberg C.G. Eur. J. Biochem. 1988; 170: 653-659Crossref PubMed Scopus (12) Google Scholar) and were at least 90% pure as monitored by SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and Coomassie Blue staining. Fractionation of cells into soluble and cytoskeletal fractions was done after lysis in the presence of Triton X-100 as described (27Fagerholm S. Prescott A. Cohen P. Gahmberg C.G. FEBS Lett. 2001; 491: 131-136Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar). The phosphorylated and unphosphorylated forms of the peptides CNPLFKpSATTTV and CLFKSApTTTVMN corresponding to the sequences surrounding phosphorylated Ser-756 and Thr-758, respectively (where pS and pT indicate phosphoserine and phosphothreonine), were coupled to vinylsulfone-activated agarose via the N-terminal cysteine residue. The cytosol and solubilized cytoskeletal fractions (0.5â1 mg of protein) were then subjected to affinity chromatography on each peptide-agarose column as described (33Valmu L. Fagerholm S. Suila H. Gahmberg C.G. Eur. J. Immunol. 1999; 29: 2107-2118Crossref PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar). For detection of the CD11/CD18 integrin with phospho-specific antibodies, the integrin was first immunoprecipitated from 2.0 to 2.5 mg of lysate protein with 20 Î¼g of R7E4 coupled noncovalently to protein G-Sepharose. Bound proteins were eluted with 1% SDS, then subjected to polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, and transferred to nitrocellulose, and the phosphorylated integrin was immunoblotted and detected using the ECL chemiluminescence detection system (Amersham Biosciences). The phosphospecific antibody that recognizes CD18 phosphorylated at Ser-745 was used at 2 Î¼g/ml in the presence of 5 Î¼g/ml unphosphorylated peptide conjugated to keyhole limpet hemocyanin. The Ser-756 phosphospecific antibody was used at the same concentration but in the presence of 25 Î¼g/ml unphosphorylated peptide conjugated to keyhole limpet hemocyanin. Incubation with both antibodies was carried out overnight in 4 Â°C. The antibody R2E7B which recognizes phosphorylated and unphosphorylated CD18 equally well was used at 1:5000 dilution. The antibody against the PKCÎ± catalytic domain, which also reacts with PKCÎ² isoforms, was used as a dilution of 1:1000. An antibody that recognizes all 14-3-3 isoforms was used at 1 Î¼g/ml. To identify the major CD18 kinases, human leukocyte lysates were initially fractionated on MonoQ. All the activity was retained by the column and eluted as one major peak (Fig.1A), which was pooled and chromatographed on heparin-Sepharose. At this step, 80% of the activity was not retained by the column, whereas 20% was bound. The activity present in both fractions was then further purified as described under âExperimental Procedures.â A flow chart of the overall purification protocol is shown in Fig.2.Figure 2Protocol for the purification of the major CD18 kinase activities in leukocyte lysates. SDS-PAGE revealed two major proteins, whose elution position correlated with activity (Fig. 3B). When the fractions were incubated with Mg[Î³-32P]ATP, both proteins became phosphorylated (Fig. 3C), suggesting that they might be protein kinases capable of autophosphorylation. The bands were excised and subjected to tryptic mass fingerprinting, which revealed that they both corresponded to the Î´-isoform of PKC. All the peptides detected were located in the catalytic domain of PKCÎ´ (Table I). This observation and the apparent molecular mass of the purified protein (which is much smaller than full-length PKCÎ´) indicated that it represented an active proteolytic fragment. Such fragments are known to be active in the absence of phospholipids and diacylglycerol, which are required for the activity of full-length PKCÎ´. The ability of copper,zinc superoxide dismutase (Cu,Zn-SOD) to catalyze autoxidation of cysteine and other thiols was investigated by measuring thiol loss and oxygen consumption. The reaction occurred equally well with the bovine and human enzymes and produced hydrogen peroxide and the corresponding disulfide. It did not occur with manganese SOD and is not, therefore, due to the dismutase activity of the enzyme. Cysteine and cysteamine were highly reactive: the Km for cysteine was 1.4 mm andVmax (with 40 Î¼g/ml SOD) 35 Î¼m/min; the equivalent values for cysteamine (with 20 Î¼g/ml SOD) were 1.4 mm and 36 Î¼m/min. With 1 mm thiol and 40 Î¼g/ml SOD, rates of oxidation of other thiols (Î¼m/min) were as follows: GSH, 1.0; dithiothreitol, 2.1; dihydrolipoic acid, 1.7; homocysteine, 1.6; cys-gly, 1.4; penicillamine, 0.6; and N-acetylcysteine, 0.1. SOD-mediated oxidation of cysteine, in the absence of chelating agents, proceeded only after a variable lag phase. The lag was decreased but not eliminated with Chelex-treated reagents and is attributed to interference by submicromolar concentrations of iron and possibly other transition metal ions. SOD-catalyzed oxidation of the other thiols was variably affected by adventitious metal ions and chelating agents. Reactions were all performed in the presence of desferrioxamine to obviate these effects. SOD-catalyzed oxidation of GSH and homocysteine was enhanced by cysteine through a thiol-disulfide exchange mechanism. This study characterizes a novel pro-oxidant thiol oxidase activity of Cu,Zn-SOD. It is a potential source of reactive oxidants and may contribute to the cytotoxicity of reactive thiols such as cysteine and cysteamine. Three forms of the enzyme, namely Cu,Zn-SOD, Mn-SOD, and extracellular Cu,Zn-SOD, are found in mammals (1Lyons T.J. Gralla E.B. Valentine J.S. Met. Ions Biol. However, thiols can act as pro-oxidants by undergoing autoxidation to produce hydrogen peroxide (13Misra H.P. J. Biol. The reaction is metal-catalyzed, with copper being a particularly effective catalyst. Autoxidation is considered to be important in the well established cytotoxicity of low molecular weight thiols (18Munday R. Adv. Pharmacol. 1994; 27: 237-270Crossref PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar, 19Held K.D. Sylvester F.C. Hopcia K.L. Biaglow J.E. Radiat. Res. 1996; 145: 542-553Crossref PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar). Cu,Zn-SOD, if it were a catalyst of this reaction, could be a promoter of thiol toxicity. We have investigated the ability of Cu,Zn-SOD to catalyze autoxidation of cysteine, GSH, and a range of physiological relevant thiols. In previous studies of superoxide-mediated thiol oxidation, we noted that addition of SOD to some thiols alone appeared to promote oxidation (10Winterbourn C.C. Metodiewa D. Free Radic. Biol. Med. 1999; 27: 322-328Crossref PubMed Scopus (655) Google Scholar). Others have made similar observations with cysteine (20Biaglow J.E. Issels R.W. Gerweck L.E. Varnes M.E. Jacobson B. Mitchell J.B. Russo A. Radiat. Res. 1984; 100: 298-312Crossref PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar, 21Saez G. Thornalley P.J. Hill H.A. Hems R. Bannister J.V. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1982; 719: 24-31Crossref PubMed Scopus (245) Google Scholar). The explanation given, that superoxide somehow protects cysteine against oxidation (13Misra H.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1974; 249: 2151-2155Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 21Saez G. Thornalley P.J. Hill H.A. Hems R. Bannister J.V. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1982; 719: 24-31Crossref PubMed Scopus (245) Google Scholar), is not consistent with current knowledge of how superoxide interacts with thiols (11Winterbourn C.C. Metodiewa D. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1994; 314: 284-290Crossref PubMed Scopus (237) Google Scholar, 12Zhang N. Schuchmann H.-P. von Sonntag C. J. Phys. Chem. 1991; 95: 4718-4722Crossref Scopus (52) Google Scholar). After further investigation, we report here that the enzyme does not act in these systems simply by dismutating superoxide. Instead, we demonstrate a novel activity of Cu,Zn-SOD, namely the catalysis of thiol oxidation by oxygen. This thiol oxidase activity is high for cysteine and cysteamine but much lower with GSH and a range of other biological thiols. Unless stated otherwise, all biochemicals, including thiol compounds, were purchased from Sigma. Catalase, bovine erythrocyte, and liver Cu,Zn-SOD, human Cu,Zn-SOD, and Mn-SOD were used without further purification. Human erythrocyte Cu,Zn-SOD was isolated in our laboratory from red cell lysate by successive chromatography on DEAE-Sepaharose and phenyl-Sepharose and ran as single band on SDS-PAGE in the same position as Sigma human Cu,Zn-SOD. SOD concentrations were determined by weight or using the Bio-Rad (Lowry-based) DC protein assay standardized with bovine serum albumin. Micromolar concentrations of the bovine enzyme were determined spectrophotometrically, using Îµ258 = 10.3 Ã 103mâ1 cmâ1 (22Rotilio G. Calabrese L. Bossa F. Barra D. Finazzi-Agro A. Mondovi B. Biochemistry. 1972; 11: 2182-2187Crossref PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar), and on this basis, 40 Î¼g/ml corresponded to 1.2 Î¼m. Where the term SOD is used in the text, it refers to the bovine erythrocyte Cu,Zn enzyme. The apoenzyme was prepared by initial dialysis against 50 mm acetate buffer, pH 3.8, + 10 mm EDTA followed by exhaustive dialysis with 0.1m NaCl to remove the bound chelator (23Valentine J.S. Pantoliano M.W. McDonnell P.J. Burger A.R. Lippard S.J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1979; 76: 4245-4249Crossref PubMed Scopus (110) Google Scholar). Dismutase activities were measured by a microtiter plate assay using WST-1 (water-soluble tetrazolium salt; Dojindo Laboratories (Kumamoto, Japan)) and a xanthine oxidase/hypoxanthine superoxide generating system (24Peskin A.V. Winterbourn C.C. Clin. Chim. Acta. 2000; 293: 157-166Crossref PubMed Scopus (395) Google Scholar). The amount of protein required per well (200 Î¼l volume) to give 50% inhibition of WST-1 reduction was 2.5 Â± 0.4, 3.3 Â± 0.4, and 2.4 Â± 0.9 ng for the bovine erythrocyte, bovine liver, and human erythrocyte enzymes, respectively. Except where indicated otherwise, buffers and thiol solutions were treated with washed Chelex 100 resin (Bio-Rad) for at least 2 h and then separated by careful decantation. Solutions were stored in plastic containers, and contact with glass was avoided. Thiols, at concentrations indicated in the appropriate figure legends, were incubated with SOD in air at 37 Â°C in a total volume of 0.5 ml of 25 mmphosphate buffer, at pH 7.4, and with catalase (10 Î¼g/ml) present unless indicated otherwise. Samples were removed at intervals and mixed with a 5,5â²-dithiobis-2-nitrobenzoic acid solution to measure free thiol concentration. Absorbances were measured on a Cary1E Spectrophotometer and thiol concentrations calculated using Îµ412 = 14,100 (25Jocelyn P.C. Jakoby W.B. Griffith O.W. Sulfur and Sulfur Amino Acids. Academic Press, New York1995: 44-67Google Scholar). With GSH, disulfide formation was detected by a glutathione reductase/NADPH system (26Beutler E. Red Cell Metabolism: A Manual of Biochemical Methods. Grune and Stratton, Orlando1984: 134Google Scholar). Oxygen consumption was measured with a Clark-type electrode (Yellow Springs Instruments Co., Yellow Springs, OH). To establish whether thiol oxidase activity was due to loosely bound metal ions, bovine Cu,Zn-SOD (2 mg/ml) was mixed with DTPA (200 Î¼m) in 25 mm phosphate buffer, pH 7.4, then after 10 min, 75 Î¼l was passed through a spin column equilibrated in the same buffer without DTPA. Cysteine oxidation was then measured with 40 Î¼g/ml SOD and 1 mm cysteine in the presence and absence of DTPA and related to dismutase activity and total protein concentration. Thiol oxidation studies were performed at pH 7.4 in the presence of catalase and, for reasons described below, 1 Î¼m desferrioxamine. Under these conditions, cysteine alone underwent no detectable oxidation, but in the presence of bovine erythrocyte Cu,Zn-SOD there was rapid thiol loss (Fig. 1). Human erythrocyte Cu,Zn-SOD and bovine liver Cu,Zn-SOD also caused cysteine oxidation at a comparable rate to those with the bovine erythrocyte enzyme. The reaction was specific to Cu,Zn-SOD, as incubation with Mn-SOD caused no loss of cysteine. This establishes that the promotion of thiol oxidation by Cu,Zn-SOD is not simply a consequence of its ability to catalyze superoxide dismutation. Copper (and/or zinc) was required to promote cysteine oxidation, as the metal-depleted apoenzyme was inactive (data not shown). SOD has a characteristic Cu(II) absorbance peak with a maximum at 680 nm (27Lyons T.J. Liu H. Goto J.J. Nersissian A. Roe J.A. Graden J.A. Cafe C. Ellerby L.M. Bredesen D.E. Gralla E.B. Valentine J.S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 12240-12244Crossref PubMed Scopus (167) Google Scholar). On addition of cysteine, there was a rapid decrease inA680 (Fig. 2), indicating that cysteine reduces the active site copper. GSH, which reacted only slowly with SOD (see below), gave no obvious absorbance loss at 680 nm. As Cu2+ is an excellent catalyst of thiol oxidation, it was important to exclude the possibility that cysteine oxidation was simply due to adventitious or loosely bound copper in the enzyme preparation. With free Cu2+, we observed oxidation of cysteine (1 mm) at a rate of 50 Î¼m/min/Î¼mCu2+, i.e. about 10 times faster on a molar basis than with SOD. Others have analyzed Sigma bovine Cu,Zn-SOD preparations and found less than 3% of the copper to be loosely bound (28Jewett S.L. Cushing S. Gillespie F. Smith D. Sparks S. Eur. J. Biochem. 1989; 180: 569-575Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar). Analyses that we performed, by the method of Crow et al. (5Crow J.P. Sampson J.B. Zhuang Y. Thompson J.A. Beckman J.S. J. Neurochem. 1997; 69: 1936-1944Crossref PubMed Scopus (429) Google Scholar), gave results consistent with this figure. To test directly if cysteine oxidation could have been caused by adventitious copper, we pretreated the SOD with a 5-fold molar excess of DTPA, then removed the DTPA on a spin column. Dismutase activities and protein concentrations were measured before and after passage through the column to account for losses. When related to either measure, rates of thiol oxidation by the treated and untreated enzyme were identical, even with three successive DTPA treatments and passages through the column. Extensive dialysis of the SOD against Chelexed phosphate buffer, either with or without pretreatment with DTPA, also did not diminish its ability to promote cysteine oxidation. Thus, it is unlikely that this activity was caused by bound copper. Cysteine loss in the presence of Cu,Zn-SOD was accompanied by oxygen consumption. The mole ratio of thiol loss to oxygen consumed, measured over 20 min in the same solution, was 3.8 Â± 0.3 (n = 4). The oxygen consumption rate was decreased, to about 73%, by the addition of catalase, suggesting that hydrogen peroxide was produced in the reaction. Any hydrogen peroxide formed would be expected to cause additional cysteine oxidation (10Winterbourn C.C. Metodiewa D. Free Radic. Biol. Med. 1999; 27: 322-328Crossref PubMed Scopus (655) Google Scholar, 29Ehrenberg L. Harms-Ringdahl M. Fedorcsak I. Granath F. Acta Chem. Scand. 1989; 43: 177-188Crossref Google Scholar). We routinely added catalase when measuring thiol oxidation to avoid complications due to this reaction. In the absence of catalase (with 1 mm cysteine and 40 Î¼g/ml SOD), cysteine oxidation was 1.38 Â± 0.12 times faster (n = 5) than with catalase present. The effect of catalase was the same at 4â20 Î¼g/ml and independent of whether the enzyme was Chelex-treated. These results are consistent with hydrogen peroxide being produced in Reaction 2 and oxidizing further cysteine as in Reaction 3.O2+2RSHâSODââH2O2+RSSRREACTION2H2O2+2RSHâ2H2O+RSSRREACTION3As described below, SOD also promoted GSH autoxidation but at a very much lower rate. Biochemistry. 1975; 14: 5294-5299Crossref Scopus (681) Google Scholar), pre-exposure of the SOD to cysteine (in the absence of catalase), then dialysis, caused no loss of dismutase activity or ability to promote further cysteine oxidation (data not shown). The reactivities of various physiologically relevant thiol compounds with bovine Cu,Zn-SOD were determined (Table I). Cysteamine reacted almost twice as rapidly as cysteine. With all the other thiols, addition of SOD caused a significant increase in oxidation rate, but they were at least 5-fold less reactive that cysteine. It is noteworthy that the major intracellular thiol, GSH, was oxidized very slowly. High activity was not simply a property of aminothiols or associated with low thiol group pK, as penicillamine was poorly oxidized. In all cases there was a statistically significant difference between thiol oxidation in the presence and absence of Cu,Zn-SOD. Although SOD showed very little oxidase activity with GSH and homocysteine, addition of cysteine promoted the oxidation of both thiols, as demonstrated by thiol loss in excess of the cysteine added (Fig. 3). DTT is frequently added at high concentration to cell extracts containing SOD. Therefore, we measured cysteine oxidation rates at higher DTT concentrations. Rates of oxidation were linear over 2 h and increased linearly with DTT concentration to approximately 0.4 mm/h with 4 mm DTT (8 mm thiol; not shown). The rates of loss of cysteine and cysteamine increased with increasing thiol concentration (Fig.4A). In each case there was evidence of saturation. With 40 Î¼g/ml (1.2 Î¼m) SOD, cysteine showed a Km of 1.4 mm andVmax of 35 Î¼m/min. Cysteamine (with 20 Î¼g/ml enzyme) also showed a Km of 1.4 mm and Vmax of 36 Î¼m/min. The rate of cysteine oxidation was linearly dependent on SOD concentration, but with cysteamine, the curve flattened above 20 Î¼g/ml enzyme (Fig. 4B). Thus at maximum efficiency, the turnover numbers for cysteine and cysteamine were â¼30 and 60/min, respectively. The rate of cysteine oxidation increased more than 10-fold when the SOD was inactivated by heating at 105 Â°C for 40 min. This is not surprising as boiling the enzyme would release the active site copper. Adding a 2- or 4-fold excess of Mn-SOD over Cu,Zn-SOD (per catalytic site) did not affect the rate of cysteine oxidation (rate with Mn-SOD = 99 Â± 10% of that without Mn-SOD,n = 4). For cysteine, under the same conditions as for Fig. 1, initial rates of oxidation at pH 7.0, 7.4, and 8.0 were 9.3 Â± 0.4, 8.9 Â± 0.1, and 9.2 Â± 0.4 Î¼m/min, respectively, indicating no pH dependence in this range. With desferrioxamine present, initial rates of SOD-mediated thiol oxidation were linear (as shown for cysteine in Fig. 1). In the absence of chelating agents, the kinetics were very different. For cysteine (Fig.5) there was a lag phase, and the overall oxidation rate was decreased. Oxidation rates varied unpredictably depending on the buffer preparation and were substantially increased, with less lag, if the reagents were treated with Chelex resin. Adding the product of the reaction, cystine, at the start did not overcome the lag (not shown). DTPA almost eliminated the lag but gave a slower overall rate than with desferrioxamine (Fig. 5). The rate of cysteine oxidation was the same in the presence of 1 or 10 Î¼mdesferrioxamine, either with 1.2 Î¼m SOD (Fig. 5) or with 6 Î¼m SOD (not shown). This indicates that it was not necessary to have as much chelator as active site copper. Rates in the presence of desferrioxamine were the same in Chelexed and unChelexed buffer (not shown). One possible explanation for the results shown in Fig. 5 is that the chelators acted by removing and activating loosely bound copper from the enzyme and that in the absence of chelator, cysteine alone slowly displaced the metal, accounting for the lag. This can be discounted on the basis that DTPA pretreatment did not decrease the activity of the enzyme (see above). Furthermore, the lag phase was still evident with SOD that had been pretreated with DTPA, and it disappeared when further DTPA was added. This suggests that the chelator was interacting with a constituent of the reaction mixture and not with the enzyme. This complex set of observations could be explained by the reagents containing trace amounts of adventitious transition metal ion(s) that affect the rate of cysteine oxidation by SOD and give rise to a lag phase. The results with desferrioxamine point to iron being involved. Ehrenberg et al. (29Ehrenberg L. Harms-Ringdahl M. Fedorcsak I. Granath F. Acta Chem. Scand. 1989; 43: 177-188Crossref Google Scholar) have noted that iron can inhibit the autoxidation of cysteine catalyzed by free copper ions. We have found this inhibition to be extremely potent, such that with 0.4 Î¼m Cu2+, ferrous sulfate has an IC50 of about 50 nm. 2R. Munday and C. Winterbourn, unpublished data. Adding submicromolar concentrations of Fe2+ ions to SOD and cysteine caused a progressive decrease in the rate of cysteine oxidation. As shown for 0.5 Î¼m iron in Fig.6, the effect of the metal was entirely abrogated by desferrioxamine. These results provide strong support for the conclusion that traces of iron (and perhaps other transition metals) in the reagents interfere with SOD-mediated cysteine oxidation and that to study the system without this complication it is necessary to add desferrioxamine. EDTA and DTPA were not as effective as desferrioxamine at eliminating the effects of adventitious metals, and in the presence or absence of either of these chelators, rates of cysteine oxidation varied in the pH 7â8 range (data not shown). SOD-mediated oxidation of the other thiols was also influenced by adventitious metals, but not necessarily in the same way as with cysteine. This complex interaction with metal ions shows similar features to their effect on thiol oxidation by free copper ions.2 A mechanistic study of the effects of trace metals and chelators on the thiol reactivity of copper and SOD will be published elsewhere. We have shown that Cu,Zn-SOD promotes the autoxidation of low molecular weight thiols. The reaction involves reduction of the active site copper, consumes oxygen, and produces hydrogen peroxide and disulfide. It is not a consequence of the dismutase activity of the enzyme, as no thiol oxidation was seen with Mn-SOD. Rather, it is a characteristic of the Cu,Zn enzyme, and as demonstrated with cysteine, the human and bovine enzymes exhibit comparable reactivity. The oxidase activity was particularly high with the aminothiols, cysteine, and cysteamine. Other thiols, including GSH, were much less reactive. It is well known that copper ions are efficient catalysts of thiol autoxidation and that aminothiols are more susceptible than DTT or GSH to copper-catalyzed oxidation (16Kachur A.V. Koch C.J. Biaglow J.E. Free Radic. Res. 1998; 28: 259-269Crossref PubMed Scopus (134) Google Scholar, 17Kachur A.V. Held K.D. Koch C.J. Biaglow J.E. Radiat. Res. 1997; 147: 409-415Crossref PubMed Scopus (59) Google Scholar, 20Biaglow J.E. Issels R.W. Gerweck L.E. Varnes M.E. Jacobson B. Mitchell J.B. Russo A. Radiat. Res. 1984; 100: 298-312Crossref PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar, 29Ehrenberg L. Harms-Ringdahl M. Fedorcsak I. Granath F. Acta Chem. Scand. 1989; 43: 177-188Crossref Google Scholar). On a molar equivalent basis, the cysteine oxidase activity we observed with SOD was about a tenth that of free Cu2+. This activity was not due to adventitious or loosely bound copper that could be removed by pretreatment of the enzyme with chelator. Bovine SOD from erythrocytes and liver, and human erythrocyte SOD prepared by two different methods, all had comparable reactivity. It is unlikely, therefore, that it was due to a contaminant or partially denatured enzyme, as these would vary between preparations. We conclude that the active site copper was involved and that Cu,Zn-SOD has thiol oxidase activity. Although less active than free copper, from a physiological perspective this activity of Cu,Zn-SOD is potentially significant. At a typical cell concentration (â¼100 Î¼g/ml), SOD acting at its maximum efficiency could consume about 0.1 mm cysteine/min, with concomitant hydrogen peroxide production. Even with GSH, which reacted more than 10 times more slowly, this reaction could be a significant source of hydrogen peroxide in the cell. Regarding the mechanism of thiol oxidation, our observation of saturating effects with cysteine and cysteamine suggests that an intermediate complex with the enzyme is involved. The lack of inhibition by excess Mn-SOD indicates that superoxide is not required to oxidize the reduced SOD. It also suggests a two-electron transfer directly from oxygen to the complex to regenerate the Cu(II) form of the enzyme and a sulfenic acid equivalent, rather than release of thiyl radicals and subsequent superoxide generation. One possibility is the scheme proposed in Reactions 4âR6, in which the sulfenic acid would react with more thiol to give the disulfide and the SOD would be available to complex more cysteine. This is similar to the inner sphere mechanism proposed for free Cu2+, although there is equivocal evidence for at least some superoxide production (13Misra H.P. J. Biol. With SOD, where there is a narrow (4 â«) hydrophobic channel (32Tainer J.A. Getzoff E.D. Richardson J.S. Richardson D.C. Nature. 1983; 306: 284-290Crossref PubMed Scopus (803) Google Scholar), it is more likely that only one cysteine could access the active site copper or that there is long range electron transfer.SODâCu2++RSHâ[SODâCu2+âRSââSODâCu+âRSâ]+H+REACTION4[SODâCu+âRSâ]+O2+H++H2OâSODâCu2++RSOH+H2O2REACTION5RSH+RSOHâRSSR+H2OREACTION6By generating hydrogen peroxide, the reaction between Cu,Zn-SOD and thiols is a potential source of reactive oxidants in biological systems. The toxicity of thiols to cells is well documented, with the aminothiols, cysteine and cysteamine, being most potent (18Munday R. Adv. Pharmacol. 1994; 27: 237-270Crossref PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar, 19Held K.D. Sylvester F.C. Hopcia K.L. Biaglow J.E. Radiat. Res. 1996; 145: 542-553Crossref PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar,33Glatt H. Protic-Sabljic M. Oesch F. Science. 1983; 220: 961-963Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar, 34Nath K.A. Salahudeen A.K. Am. J. Physiol. 1993; 264: F306-F314PubMed Google Scholar, 35Issels R.D. Biaglow J.E. Epstein L. Gerweck L.E. Cancer Res. 1984; 44: 3911-3915PubMed Google Scholar, 36Starkebaum G. Harlan J.M. J. Clin. Invest. 1986; 77: 1370-1376Crossref PubMed Scopus (772) Google Scholar, 37Held K.D. Biaglow J.E. Radiat. Res. 1993; 134: 375-382Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar, 38Starkebaum G. Root R.K. J. Immunol. 1985; 134: 3371-3378PubMed Google Scholar). In a number of these studies, hydrogen peroxide formed by autoxidation has been implicated in the toxicity and a copper-mediated mechanism proposed. Our results suggest that physiologically, Cu,Zn-SOD is a likely catalyst of this reaction. There are other instances where Cu,Zn-SOD has been seen to enhance the toxicity of cysteine (39Carlsson J. Granberg G.P. Nyberg G.K. Edlund M.B. Appl. Environ. Microbiol. 1979; 37: 383-390Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 40Nyberg G.K. Granberg G.P. Carlsson J. Appl. Environ. Microbiol. 1979; 38: 29-34Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The effect was attributed to copper released from the enzyme damaged by oxidative modification, but our findings suggest that SOD itself may have been responsible. GSH was much less reactive than cysteine and was minimally oxidized in our experimental system. This low reactivity should allow millimolar concentrations of GSH to coexist with Cu,Zn-SOD in the cell without generating large amounts of peroxide. This would not be true for cysteine. Maintenance of low cyst(e)ine concentrations and evolution of GSH as the major cytosolic thiol have largely alleviated the pro-oxidant threat of SOD and readily oxidized thiols. Radical scavenging by GSH generates superoxide, so that for effective radical removal, the concerted action of GSH and SOD is required (8Munday R. Winterbourn C.C. Biochem. Pharmacol. 1989; 38: 4349-4352Crossref PubMed Scopus (128) Google Scholar, 9Winterbourn C.C. Free Radic. Biol. Med. 1993; 14: 85-90Crossref PubMed Scopus (323) Google Scholar). The low reactivity between the two should not compromise this antioxidant function. Intracellular GSH could, however, contribute to the toxicity of reactive thiols such as cysteine. We observed that small amounts of cysteine promoted autoxidation of GSH, presumably via SOD-catalyzed oxidation of cysteine and a disulfide exchange mechanism to recycle the cystine formed. An elevation in intracellular cyst(e)ine, therefore, has the potential to expose all the GSH to oxidation. With enzymatic recycling of the GSSG, this could generate large amounts of hydrogen peroxide. Promotion of homocysteine oxidation by cysteine and SOD was also observed. Elevated homocysteine is a recognized risk factor in cardiovascular disease (41Stamler J.S. Slivka A. Nutr. Rev. 1996; 54: 1-30Crossref PubMed Scopus (230) Google Scholar), and production of superoxide and hydrogen peroxide from homocysteine autoxidation could be a contributing factor to the disease (42Harrison D.G. J. Clin. Invest. 1997; 100: 2153-2157Crossref PubMed Scopus (901) Google Scholar). Autoxidation of homocysteine is slow, even in the presence of copper ions, but it can be accelerated by small amounts of cyst(e)ine (43Hogg N. Free Radic. Biol Med. 1999; 27: 28-33Crossref PubMed Scopus (109) Google Scholar). Our finding that the same occurs with Cu,Zn-SOD suggests that it may be more relevant than copper as a physiologically catalyst. Of the other thiols we examined, Cys-Gly and dihydrolipoic acid showed comparable reactivity to GSH with Cu,Zn-SOD, whereas penicillamine andN-acetylcysteine were less reactive. Especially at the concentrations likely to be encountered physiologically, we would predict they would cause little oxidative stress. DTT is frequently added to cell extracts or biological samples in high millimolar concentrations. Therefore, its reaction with Cu,Zn-SOD has practical implications. Even though relatively slow, this reaction would be expected to give a steady rate of hydrogen peroxide production and may result in oxidative inactivation of extract constituents. We observed that Cu,Zn-SOD-mediated thiol oxidation was influenced by adventitious metal ions. Whether this is relevant in a physiological context is unclear, but it has practical implications. Initially we observed highly variable and unpredictable kinetics of cysteine oxidation, which we now attribute to interference by traces of iron and possibly other metal ions that we were unable to remove from the reagents. Oxidation of other thiols was also affected, in ways that we shall describe in more detail elsewhere. Interference was eliminated by adding micromolar desferrioxamine. DTPA also affected the oxidation rate, but its effect was not identical to that of desferrioxamine, and it is likely that iron complexed to DTPA still influences the reaction. Thus, experimenters should be aware that Cu,Zn-SOD-mediated thiol oxidation is open to interference by adventitious metal ions and that this will vary depending on the purity of reagents, pH, and whether a chelator is present. Desferrioxamine can be added to overcome this complication. We have no simple explanation for how metal ions inhibit cysteine oxidation by Cu,Zn-SOD. Substoichiometric amounts relative to the active site copper were effective, suggesting that the mechanism involves interference with electron transfer between the cysteine-copper complex and oxygen rather than forming a more oxygen-resistant complex. We and others (29Ehrenberg L. Harms-Ringdahl M. Fedorcsak I. Granath F. Acta Chem. Scand. 1989; 43: 177-188Crossref Google Scholar) have shown that low iron concentrations inhibit cysteine oxidation by free copper, and it is likely that a similar mechanism is involved with SOD. Although SOD has generally been considered strictly as an enzyme that breaks down superoxide, there is interest in other possible activities, particularly in the context of its association with familial amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (1Lyons T.J. Gralla E.B. Valentine J.S. Met. Ions Biol. Syst. 1999; 36: 125-177PubMed Google Scholar). Peroxidase activity that proceeds via the oxidation of bicarbonate to a radical cation has been documented for Cu,Zn-SOD (2Hodgson E.K. Fridovich I. Biochemistry. 1975; 14: 5294-5299Crossref Scopus (681) Google Scholar, 3Yim M.B. Boon Chock P. Stadtman E.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 4099-4105Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 4Goss S.P. Singh R.J. Kalyanaraman B. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 28233-28239Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (87) Google Scholar) as has catalysis of tyrosine nitration via peroxynitrite (5Crow J.P. Sampson J.B. Zhuang Y. Thompson J.A. Beckman J.S. J. Neurochem. 1997; 69: 1936-1944Crossref PubMed Scopus (429) Google Scholar). Cu,Zn-SOD has been reported to cause breakdown of nitrosothiols to generate NO (44Jourd'heuil D. Laroux F.S. Miles A.M. Wink D.A. Grisham M.B. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1999; 361: 323-330Crossref PubMed Scopus (114) Google Scholar), although others propose that this involves hydrogen peroxide-mediated release of copper (45Singh R.J. Hogg N. Goss S.P. Antholine W.E. Kalyanaraman B. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1999; 372: 8-15Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar). This activity appears to be 2â3-fold higher with mutants associated with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (46Johnson M.A. Macdonald T.L. Mannick J.B. Conaway M.R. Gaston B. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 39872-39878Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar). Liochev and Fridovich have addressed the question of whether the superoxide oxidase and reductase activities of SOD can be dissociated (6Liochev S.I. Fridovich I. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 38482-38485Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar) and proposed a superoxide reductase activity of Cu,Zn-SOD in the catalysis of 3-hydroxyanthranilic acid oxidation (7Liochev S.I. Fridovich I. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 2001; 388: 281-284Crossref PubMed Scopus (8) Google Scholar). With thiols, we suggest that the enzyme does not classify as a superoxide reductase but rather acts as a thiol oxidase. This novel pro-oxidant function of Cu,Zn-SOD has the potential to generate substantial amounts of hydrogen peroxide and may contribute to the toxicity of thiols such as cysteine and cysteamine and the disruption of cellular thiol equilibrium. We are grateful to Dr. Rex Munday for sharing information on copper-catalyzed thiol oxidation and to both him and Dr. Tony Kettle for helpful discussion.

The Mu transpositional DNA recombination machinery selects target sites by assembling a protein-DNA complex that interacts with the target DNA and reacts whenever it locates a favorable sequence composition. Splicing of a transposon into the target generates a 5-bp duplication that reflects the original target site. Preferential usage of different target pentamers was examined with a minimal Mu in vitro system and quantitatively compiled consensus sequences for the most preferred and the least preferred sites were generated. When analyzed as base steps, preferences toward certain steps along the 5-bp target site were detected. We further show that insertion sites can be predicted on the basis of additively calculated base step values. Also surrounding sequences influence the preference of a given pentamer; a symmetrical structural component was revealed, suggesting potential hinges at and around the target site. The Mu transpositional DNA recombination machinery selects target sites by assembling a protein-DNA complex that interacts with the target DNA and reacts whenever it locates a favorable sequence composition. Splicing of a transposon into the target generates a 5-bp duplication that reflects the original target site. Preferential usage of different target pentamers was examined with a minimal Mu in vitro system and quantitatively compiled consensus sequences for the most preferred and the least preferred sites were generated. When analyzed as base steps, preferences toward certain steps along the 5-bp target site were detected. We further show that insertion sites can be predicted on the basis of additively calculated base step values. Also surrounding sequences influence the preference of a given pentamer; a symmetrical structural component was revealed, suggesting potential hinges at and around the target site. restriction endonucleases nucleotides Transposons are mobile genetic elements that are able to translocate from site to site within and between the genomes of their host organisms by a special form of DNA recombination called DNA transposition (1Mizuuchi K. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1992; 61: 1011-1051Crossref PubMed Scopus (308) Google Scholar, 2Mizuuchi K. Genes Cells. 1997; 2: 1-12Crossref PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar). These ubiquitous residents of the genomes of all organisms generate insertional mutations and mediate various types of other genome rearrangements, thereby creating an important source of genetic variation (3Berg D.E. Howe M.M. Mobile DNA. American Society for Microbiology, Washington, D. C.1989Google Scholar, 4Sherrat D.J. Mobile Genetic Elements. Oxford University Press, Oxford, UK1995Google Scholar, 5Saedler H. Gierl A. Curr. Top. Microbiol. Immunol. 1996; 204Google Scholar). DNA transposition also has a role in the life cycles of certain bacteriophages, such as Mu (6Chaconas G. Lavoie B.D. Watson M.A. Curr. Biol. 1996; 6: 817-820Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar). In eukaryotic cells, retroviruses and certain retrotransposons integrate into the host chromosome using a chemically similar reaction (7Craig N.L. Science. 1995; 270: 253-254Crossref PubMed Scopus (142) Google Scholar, 8Haren L. Ton-Hoang B. Chandler M. Annu. Rev. Microbiol. 1999; 53: 245-281Crossref PubMed Scopus (197) Google Scholar). Transposition chemistry is also utilized for V(D)J recombination, suggesting an ancestral transpositional origin for this important DNA rearrangement reaction (9Hiom K. Melek M. Gellert M. Cell. 1998; 94: 463-470Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (424) Google Scholar, 10Agrawal A. Eastman Q.M. Schatz D.G. Nature. 1998; 394: 744-751Crossref PubMed Scopus (598) Google Scholar).Transposons utilize a common reaction mechanism (Fig. 1) for the DNA breakage reaction and for the joining of the transposon (donor DNA) ends to the target DNA (1Mizuuchi K. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1992; 61: 1011-1051Crossref PubMed Scopus (308) Google Scholar, 6Chaconas G. Lavoie B.D. Watson M.A. Curr. Biol. 1996; 6: 817-820Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar, 7Craig N.L. Science. 1995; 270: 253-254Crossref PubMed Scopus (142) Google Scholar). These two critical reaction steps, donor cleavage and strand transfer, are catalyzed by transposase proteins that initially bind sequence-specifically to the transposon ends and then synapse the ends in a protein-DNA complex called a transpososome, within which the chemical reactions then proceed. The chemistry of DNA transposition reactions is relatively well characterized (2Mizuuchi K. Genes Cells. 1997; 2: 1-12Crossref PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar, 11Kennedy A.K. Haniford D.B. Mizuuchi K. Cell. 2000; 101: 295-305Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar), mostly because of reconstituted in vitro systems and to conserved reaction mechanisms. However, less is known about the details regarding how transposons find, select, capture, and interact with their target DNA (12Craig N.L. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1997; 66: 437-474Crossref PubMed Scopus (216) Google Scholar). The choice of the integration site can have significant consequences not only for the host organism but also for the transposon itself. Therefore, uncovering the principles of target site selection will reveal important details about the behavior of mobile elements in general. In addition, the current utilization of transposons as molecular tools in vitro is expected to benefit substantially from such information.Transposons select target sites at various, and often intertwined levels, ranging from the broader âregional levelâ to the more fundamental sequence level, which includes a spectrum from sequence-specific to nearly random sites. In addition to the transposase, other transposon-specific or host proteins may also influence target site selection. Therefore, distinguishing between different causing agents and/or combinations can be difficult, especially when analyzed in vivo. For example, the bacterial transposon Tn7 encodes multiple transposase genes(tnsABCDE), which enable it to show an elaborate target site selection arsenal (13Craig N.L. Mol. Microbiol. 1991; 5: 2569-2573Crossref PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar, 14Craig N.L. Curr. Top. Microbiol. Immunol. 1996; 204: 27-48PubMed Google Scholar). TnsABC+ TnsD proteins promote high frequency insertion into a specific attTn7 site in theEscherichia coli genome (13Craig N.L. Mol. Microbiol. 1991; 5: 2569-2573Crossref PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar, 14Craig N.L. Curr. Top. Microbiol. Immunol. 1996; 204: 27-48PubMed Google Scholar). TnsD binds to theattTn7 site sequence-specifically, and induces DNA distortion that can be recognized by TnsC, which in turn activates the TnsAB machinery (15Kuduvalli P.N. Rao J.E. Craig N.L. EMBO J. 2001; 20: 924-932Crossref PubMed Scopus (59) Google Scholar, 16Rao J.E. Miller P.S. Craig N.L. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2000; 97: 3936-3941Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar). If the attTn7 site is not available, TnsABC +TnsE proteins mediate low frequency insertion into unrelated sites (17Kubo K.M. Craig N.L. J. Bacteriol. 1990; 172: 2774-2778Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 18Peters J.E. Craig N.L. Mol. Cell. 2000; 6: 573-582Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar). Regional target preferences can guide transposons to certain regions of their host genome, such as transcriptionally silenced regions with altered chromatin structure or regions upstream of RNA polymerase III-transcribed genes (yeast Ty-elements; Ref. 19Boeke J.D. Devine S.E. Cell. 1998; 93: 1087-1089Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (109) Google Scholar). Some transposons, such as Mu, Tn7, and the Tn3 family, avoid insertion into themselves and show âtarget immunityâ (12Craig N.L. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1997; 66: 437-474Crossref PubMed Scopus (216) Google Scholar), which can be regarded as a form of regional selection.Most commonly, transposons insert into non-random positions with variable levels of sequence preference detectable within the duplicated target sequence (12Craig N.L. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1997; 66: 437-474Crossref PubMed Scopus (216) Google Scholar). For example, the bacterial transposon Tn10/IS10 prefers the sequence 5â²-NGCTNAGCN-3â² (20Halling S.M. Kleckner N. Cell. 1982; 28: 155-163Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (112) Google Scholar, 21Bender J. Kleckner N. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 7996-8000Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar), while the Tc1/mariner family elements always insert into a TA (22Van Luenen H.G.A.M. Colloms S.D. Plasterk H.A. Cell. 1994; 79: 293-301Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (164) Google Scholar,23Van Luenen H.G.A.M. Plasterk H.A. Nucleic Acids Res. 1994; 22: 262-269Crossref PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar). In some cases, preferences can also be detected in the region surrounding the duplicated sequence. For example, Tc1 prefers the TA embedded in CAYA-TA-TRTG (24Ketting R.F. Fisher S.E.J. Plasterk R.H.A. Nucleic Acids Res. 1997; 25: 4041-4047Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar) and Tn5/IS50 prefers A-GNTYWRANC-T within a cluster of similar sequences (25Goryshin I.Y. Miller J.A. Kil Y.V. Lanzov V.A. Reznikoff W.S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1998; 95: 10716-10721Crossref PubMed Scopus (110) Google Scholar). Certain target DNA structures can also be preferred. For example, IS231A recognizes a consensus within an apparent S-shaped DNA structure (26Hallet B. RezsoÌhazy R. Mahillon J. Delcour J. Mol. Microbiol. 1994; 14: 131-139Crossref PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar). Similarly, DNA bent around nucleosomes and cruciform DNA are favored as retroviral integration target sites in vitro (27Muller H-P. Varmus H.E. EMBO J. 1994; 13: 4704-4714Crossref PubMed Scopus (179) Google Scholar, 28Katz R.A. Gravuer K. Skalka A.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 24190-24195Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar). The DNA sequence-related structure has been proposed for Tn10 target site flanking sequences (21Bender J. Kleckner N. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 7996-8000Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar, 29Pribil P.A. Haniford D.B. J. Mol. Biol. 2000; 303: 145-159Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar) and P element insertion sites (30Liao G-C. Rehm E.J. Rubin G.M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2000; 97: 3347-3351Crossref PubMed Scopus (164) Google Scholar).The bacteriophage Mu DNA transposition reaction mechanism is one of the most extensively studied. In vivo and in certain conditions with plasmid substrates in vitro, the Mu transposition reaction is complex (1Mizuuchi K. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1992; 61: 1011-1051Crossref PubMed Scopus (308) Google Scholar, 6Chaconas G. Lavoie B.D. Watson M.A. Curr. Biol. 1996; 6: 817-820Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar). It involves: (i) the catalytic MuA transposase assembled into a tetramer, (ii) the two ends of the genome containing the MuA binding sites, (iii) a number of accessory proteins, and (iv) DNA cofactors. The accessory proteins include a host-encoded DNA bending protein, HU and a phage-encoded activator protein, MuB (31Baker T.A. Mizuuchi M. Mizuuchi K. Cell. 1991; 65: 1003-1013Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar). The MuB protein stimulates intermolecular strand transfer in the presence of ATP (32Maxwell A. Craigie R. Mizuuchi K. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1987; 84: 699-703Crossref PubMed Scopus (91) Google Scholar) by binding to targets without Mu end sequences; thereby Mu avoids self-insertion (33Adzuma K. Mizuuchi K. Cell. 1988; 53: 257-266Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (94) Google Scholar). However, in certain in vitro conditions the Mu transposition reaction can be performed with only MuA, short Mu right-end donor DNA, and target DNA as minimal macromolecular components (Ref. 34Savilahti H. Rice P.A. Mizuuchi K. EMBO J. 1995; 14: 4893-4903Crossref PubMed Scopus (144) Google Scholar, Fig.1).Early experiments suggested that bacteriophage Mu transposes essentially randomly into a number of target sites in the host genome (35Bukhari A.I. Zipser D. Nature New Biol. 1972; 236: 240-243Crossref Scopus (93) Google Scholar, 36Daniell E. Roberts R. Abelson J. J. Mol. Biol. 1972; 69: 1-8Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar, 37Couturier M. Cell. 1976; 7: 155-163Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar). However, a closer examination in vivo revealed some degree of non-randomness in targeting (38Raibaud O. Roa M. Braun-Breton C. Schwartz M. Mol. Gen. Genet. 1979; 179: 241-248Crossref Scopus (59) Google Scholar, 39Silhavy T.J. Brickman E. Bassford P.J. Casabadan M.J. Shuman H.A. Schwartz M. Beckwith J.R. Mol. Gen.
