J. Bacteriol. 1991; 173: 1339-1343Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), and later, a preference was observed e.g. toward the control region oflacZ when it is not being transcribed (42Wang X. Higgins P.N. Mol. Microbiol. 1994; 12: 665-677Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar). Phage genome-host DNA junction sequence determination revealed some preference (43Kamp D. Kahman R. Cold Spring Harbor Symp. Quant. Biol. 1980; 45: 329-336Crossref Google Scholar) at the 5-bp target site duplication (44Allet B. Cell. 1979; 16: 123-129Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar, 45Kahman R. Kamp D. Nature. 1979; 280: 247-250Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar). An analysis of junction sequences of mini-Mu insertion sites further revealed a similar consensus sequence of duplication (5â²-NY(G/C)RN-3â²) from in vivo and in vitro transposition (46Mizuuchi M. Mizuuchi K. Cold Spring Harbor Symp. Quant. Biol. 1993; 58: 515-523Crossref PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar). An identical consensus was obtained from in vitro reactions containing MuA and HU, either with or without MuB. In addition, a regional target site preference was associated with DNA stretches exhibiting high affinity for the MuB protein (46Mizuuchi M. Mizuuchi K. Cold Spring Harbor Symp. Quant. Biol. 1993; 58: 515-523Crossref PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar).Sequence-level target site selection is difficult to study in vivo because multiple selection factors can act together. The minimal Mu in vitro transposition assay enables the analysis of target site selection under controlled reaction conditions. Therefore, we set up a direct nucleotide level in vitroassay, in which the target choice is influenced by MuA transposase alone. Quantified data were analyzed for the most favored and disfavored target sequences, not only as base pairs, but also as base pair steps that dictate the local DNA structure. Our studies reveal a new perspective on target site selection and a novel means to predict pentamer preference, which was verified by the successful design of preferred target sites within non-preferred sequences. The impact of the surrounding sequences on target site selection was examined, and symmetrical patterns spanning a â¼23â24-bp region around the target pentamer were detected in several DNA structural parameters, suggesting a large DNA binding area for the transpososome and potential hinge regions in the target DNA.DISCUSSIONThe protein-DNA complexes, transpososomes, form the machinery by which a mobile element finds and ultimately selects its destination target site. While regional target selection can be modulated by contacts between transpososomes and accessory factors bound to, or included within, the DNA structure, the final DNA-protein interactions between the target site and the transpososome nevertheless govern fundamental sequence-level selection. To circumvent complications associated with multiple level selection schemes, we studied Mu target site preference with a minimal component in vitro system that only includes features for basic level protein-DNA recognition. A quantitative assay was developed by which populations of transposition reaction products can be analyzed in a single reaction and the differential usage of phosphodiester bonds can be quantified directly from the intensity of the autoradiographic bands. No amplification step is needed to enhance signals and therefore artifactual biases in quantification are avoided. A similar assay has been used to analyze sequence-dependent bending parameters of DNA trinucleotides by DNaseI binding (56Brukner I. Sanchez R. Suck D. Pongor S. EMBO J. 1995; 14: 1812-1818Crossref PubMed Scopus (254) Google Scholar).Nucleotide and Dinucleotide Consensus Describe the Preferred Target SitesThe nucleotide consensus (C-Py-(G/C)-Pu-G) described here is generally in accordance with previously published in vivoand in vitro data (46Mizuuchi M. Mizuuchi K. Cold Spring Harbor Symp. Quant. Biol. 1993; 58: 515-523Crossref PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar), except for additional statistically significant preferences at positions 1 and 5 in our data. Some preference for these two positions, based on in vivo data, has also been proposed by Kamp and Kahmann (43Kamp D. Kahman R. Cold Spring Harbor Symp. Quant. Biol. 1980; 45: 329-336Crossref Google Scholar). The reasons for differences at these positions can be complex, including different reaction conditions in vivo compared with in vitro with additional protein factors (MuB, HU), the low number of insertions examined, and interpretation difficulties in using sequencing with termination chemistry. Previously, the consensus for the disfavored target sites has been either ignored, or deduced to be opposite to the sites that were inserted, picked for sequencing, and thus designated as preferred sites (57Davies C.J. Hutchison III, C.A. Nucleic Acids Res. 1995; 23: 507-514Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar). From our data set we could actually analyze also the least preferred sites and compile a consensus that is based on the observations made.Because target site selection of phage Mu transposition is relatively flexible, recognition may be based on DNA structure in addition to, or instead of, the actual sequence. Generally, purine-pyrimidine steps stack more stably than purine-purine or pyrimidine-pyrimidine steps. Pyrimidine-purine steps are the least stably stacked and are known to generate protein-induced kinks (58Lilley D.M.J. DNA-Protein: Structural Interactions. Oxford University Press, Oxford, UK1995Google Scholar). Some dinucleotides are especially flexible (CA/TG, TA), bistable (GG/CC, CG, AG/CT, TA) or rigid (AA/TT, AT, GA/TC) (58Lilley D.M.J. DNA-Protein: Structural Interactions. Oxford University Press, Oxford, UK1995Google Scholar). Flexible or bistable dinucleotides are preferred at central positions, and either bistable or rigid base steps are favored at the edges of the 5-bp target site core (Fig. 5,AâC).Apparent Symmetry in Target Site SelectionThe nucleotide consensus of preferred target sites (Fig. 4, A andB) demonstrates clear 2-fold inverted symmetry (palindromy). Symmetry is also detected at the dinucleotide level (Fig. 5,A and B), where it reflects the Watson-Crick base pairing rules of the double-stranded DNA (AC/GT, AT, GC, AG/CT, GG/CC, AA/TT, GA/TC, TA, CA/TG, CG). Biochemical data on Mu transposition complexes indicate that the active sites of two of the four MuA protomers promote cleavage and strand transfer reactions at the two ends of the element (59Williams T.L. Jackson E.L. Caritte A. Baker T.A. Genes Dev. 1999; 13: 2725-2737Crossref PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar). The apparent symmetry arises from this functional 2-fold symmetry of the transposition reaction: MuA monomers and the right-end donor fragments are functionally symmetrical in our assay. Because the transposition complex is most probably symmetrical also relative to target DNA, recognition is possible in both orientations without affecting specific contacts. Therefore, it is impossible to deduce the orientation in which each sequence should be aligned and the consensus inevitably appears somewhat palindromic, even if individual targets are asymmetric. Within the 10% of the most preferred pentamers (n = 77), palindromy is not more prevalent than within a random set (data not shown). Taken together, the above reasoning suggests caution in the interpretation of the consensus sequence data in general. A consensus does not represent the best individual target site, but an average. Apparent palindromy or symmetry has been noticed in several earlier studies on target site selection of transposition (Tn10, Ref. 21Bender J. Kleckner N. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 7996-8000Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar; Tn3, Ref. 57Davies C.J. Hutchison III, C.A. Nucleic Acids Res. 1995; 23: 507-514Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar; Tn5, Ref. 25Goryshin I.Y. Miller J.A. Kil Y.V. Lanzov V.A. Reznikoff W.S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1998; 95: 10716-10721Crossref PubMed Scopus (110) Google Scholar; IS231A, Ref. 26Hallet B. RezsoÌhazy R. Mahillon J. Delcour J. Mol. Microbiol. 1994; 14: 131-139Crossref PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar; IS903, Ref. 60Hu W-Y. Thompson W. Lawrence C.E. Derbyshire K.M. J. Mol. Biol. 2001; 306: 403-416Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar; Tc1, Ref. 24Ketting R.F. Fisher S.E.J. Plasterk R.H.A. Nucleic Acids Res. 1997; 25: 4041-4047Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar; P element, Ref. 30Liao G-C. Rehm E.J. Rubin G.M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2000; 97: 3347-3351Crossref PubMed Scopus (164) Google Scholar).Insertion Sites Can Be PredictedDinucleotide data can be used to predict the preference for each pentamer. Analysis of â¼80% of all possible pentamers was adequate for the statistical prediction of expected preference of pentamers (Fig. 6A). Based on dinucleotide data, new target molecules can be designed for various purposes, e.g. to contain only one major target site (Fig.6B). This kind of target is essential for protein-DNA cross-linking experiments to further probe the contacts between the transpososome and target site. Predicting potential insertion sites is also valuable for experiments where Mu transposition is utilized as a tool for sequencing or generating insertion mutant pools. It may also be feasible to make computational predictions that would take into account structural preferences in addition to pentamer sequence.The Effect of Surrounding SequencesThe pentamer sequence explained 62% of the observed variances, and the flanking sequences contributed significantly to the attractiveness of target pentamers. If the flanking sequences contribute, either there must be protein contacts with a wider area around the duplicated pentamer, or the sequence context affects the conformation of the target pentamer (e.g. widening or tightening B-DNA grooves). But how large is this effective area? Although this question can ultimately be answered by protein-DNA cross-linking experiments or with structural information obtained from target-capture complexes, some leads can be found in our data. The first lead was seen when the structural parameters were analyzed (Fig. 7A) and symmetrical patterns were seen extending well beyond the pentamer target site, some 9â10 nucleotides to the flanking areas. The second parallel clue comes from an experiment in which we examined how close to the DNA edge Mu transposes. We found that when a preferred pentamer is positioned 10-bp from the DNA end, it can be used as an effective target (data not shown), whereas the same pentamer positioned 5-bp from the end remains without insertions. Taken together, these results suggest that the Mu transpososome probably makes contacts with (or is influenced by) a target covering a region up to 23â25 bp. A broad zone of contacts (â¼24-bp) has been detected with contact-probing experiments between the transpososome and target DNA in the target-capture complex of Tn10 (29Pribil P.A. Haniford D.B. J. Mol. Biol. 2000; 303: 145-159Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar). For IS903 a preferred target has been found to consist of a 21-bp palindromic sequence pattern, with preferred 5-bp sequences in the flanks around a 9-bp target duplication area (60Hu W-Y. Thompson W. Lawrence C.E. Derbyshire K.M. J. Mol. Biol. 2001; 306: 403-416Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar). Therefore, a broad zone of contacts may be a more general feature in transpososome-target recognition.What Kinds of Protein-DNA Contacts Could Be Made?Protein-DNA contacts can be generated through direct readout of specific bases or indirect readout through DNA backbone contacts with phosphate groups and/or sugar residues. Clear base preferences were noted in the 5-bp target core, while outside this target core limited preference was only seen in position 3 (data not shown). Symmetrical alterations in the GC preference were noted in the target area extending to flanks on either side of the pentamer (Fig. 7, upper panel). Because no clear sequence preference was observed in the surrounding sequences, contacts conceivably could be made through indirect readout. Sequence-related structural parameters spatially position the hydrogen bonding donor and acceptor sites and the phosphate backbone in a way that can be recognized with sufficient specificity. Pyrimidine-purine dimers are especially easy to deform in protein-DNA complexes and they act as flexible hinges, fitting the DNA onto the protein surface (52Olson W.K. Gorin A.A. Lu X-J. Hock L.M. Zhurkin V.B. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1998; 95: 11163-11168Crossref PubMed Scopus (869) Google Scholar). In our analysis three peaks are observed for the protein-induced deformability. The periodicity of these peaks (9â10 nt) is close to the B-DNA helical pitch (10.5 bp) and thus can be indicative of anisotropic bending.Target recognition can be defined as fitting the target DNA to the protein active site via optimization of contacts made. This can be an additive process, as suggested for IHF binding by Rice et al. (61Rice P.A. Yang S-W. Mizuuchi K. Nash H.A. Cell. 1996; 87: 1295-1306Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (648) Google Scholar) and for Tn10 transposase target recognition by Pribil and Haniford (29Pribil P.A. Haniford D.B. J. Mol. Biol. 2000; 303: 145-159Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar). Transpososome binding to the consensus base pairs may facilitate a kink formation, which in turn would permit additional contacts with flanking DNA. In Mu target site recognition, the three protein-induced deformability areas may act as hinges (as suggested above) in a similar additive, sequential process. If the duplicated pentamer is surrounded by a poor sequence, i.e. unable to form suitable hinges, then potential contacts to the flanks are partly omitted and the transpososome is more prone to dissociate and locate another target site.A Combination of Regional and Sequence-level Target Site SelectionProtein-protein interactions were suggested to explain results of DNase I footprinting experiments, where regionally preferred sites were observed clustered next to, but not within, the MuB footprint area (46Mizuuchi M. Mizuuchi K. Cold Spring Harbor Symp. Quant. Biol. 1993; 58: 515-523Crossref PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar). One possibility to explain these results was that MuB binds some regions of target DNA preferentially, delivers transpososomes to the region, activates the complex for strand transfer, and allows the complex to diffuse along target DNA before strand transfer (46Mizuuchi M. Mizuuchi K. Cold Spring Harbor Symp. Quant. Biol. 1993; 58: 515-523Crossref PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar). MuA can then select the exact sequence-level target site, which explains the similar consensus sequence results obtained from experiments either with or without MuB (Ref. 46Mizuuchi M. Mizuuchi K. Cold Spring Harbor Symp. Quant. Biol. 1993; 58: 515-523Crossref PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar; this study). Transposons are mobile genetic elements that are able to translocate from site to site within and between the genomes of their host organisms by a special form of DNA recombination called DNA transposition (1Mizuuchi K. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1992; 61: 1011-1051Crossref PubMed Scopus (308) Google Scholar, 2Mizuuchi K. Genes Cells. 1997; 2: 1-12Crossref PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar). These ubiquitous residents of the genomes of all organisms generate insertional mutations and mediate various types of other genome rearrangements, thereby creating an important source of genetic variation (3Berg D.E. Howe M.M. Mobile DNA. American Society for Microbiology, Washington, D. C.1989Google Scholar, 4Sherrat D.J. Mobile Genetic Elements. Oxford University Press, Oxford, UK1995Google Scholar, 5Saedler H. Gierl A. Curr. Top. Microbiol. Immunol. 1996; 204Google Scholar). DNA transposition also has a role in the life cycles of certain bacteriophages, such as Mu (6Chaconas G. Lavoie B.D. Watson M.A. Curr. Biol. 1996; 6: 817-820Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar). In eukaryotic cells, retroviruses and certain retrotransposons integrate into the host chromosome using a chemically similar reaction (7Craig N.L. Science. 1995; 270: 253-254Crossref PubMed Scopus (142) Google Scholar, 8Haren L. Ton-Hoang B. Chandler M. Annu. Rev. Microbiol. 1999; 53: 245-281Crossref PubMed Scopus (197) Google Scholar). Transposition chemistry is also utilized for V(D)J recombination, suggesting an ancestral transpositional origin for this important DNA rearrangement reaction (9Hiom K. Melek M. Gellert M. Cell. 1998; 94: 463-470Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (424) Google Scholar, 10Agrawal A. Eastman Q.M. Schatz D.G. Nature. 1998; 394: 744-751Crossref PubMed Scopus (598) Google Scholar). Transposons utilize a common reac

Synthetic oligomers of the antigenicCandida albicans (1â2)-Î²-mannopyranans adopt a compact solution conformation that leads to numerous inter-residue nuclear Overhauser effects, including unprecedented nuclear Overhauser effects between n and n + 3 residues. In excellent agreement with experimentally determined distances, unrestrained molecular dynamics point to a single family of conformations that approximate a compact helical motif with a three-residue repeat for this unique homopolymer. When the synthetic di- to hexasaccharides were employed as inhibitors of monoclonal antibodies, which protect mice against a lethal dose of the yeast pathogen, a novel pattern of inhibitor activity was observed. Instead of the paradigm first reported by Kabat (Kabat, E. A. (1962) Fed. Proc. 21, 694â701; Kabat, E. A. (1966) J. Immunol. 97, 1â11), wherein homo-oligosaccharides exhibit increasing inhibitory activity with increasing size, here the maximum activity is reached for di- and trisaccharides and diminishes significantly for tetra-, penta-, and hexasaccharides. These immunochemical data correlate with the ordered conformation of the Î²-1,2-linked mannopyranan and imply that a uniquely small antigenic determinant has potential as a component of synthetic conjugate vaccines against Candida albicans. Cutler J.E. Infect. Immun. 1995; 63: 2714-2719Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 2Han Y. Cutler J.E. J. Infect. Dis. 1997; 175: 1169-1175Crossref PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar, 3Han Y. Riesselman M.H. Cutler J.E. Infect. Immun. 2000; 68: 1649-1654Crossref PubMed Scopus (151) Google Scholar), have been shown to be specific for a cell wall (1â2)-Î²-mannan antigen (4Shibata N. Kobayashi H. Tojo M. Suzuki S. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1986; 251: 697-708Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar, 5Shibata N. Fukasawa S. Kobayashi H. Tojo M Yonezu T. Ambo A. Ohkubo Y. Suzuki S. Carbohydr. Res. 1989; 187: 239-253Crossref PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar). The unique immunochemical properties of this antigen correlate with its solution conformation and show a sharp contrast with the paradigm first reported by Kabat (6Kabat E.A. Fed. Proc. 1962; 21: 694-701Google Scholar, 7Kabat E.A. J. Immunol. 1966; 97: 1-11PubMed Google Scholar) some 40 years ago that applies to the majority of oligosaccharide-antibody interactions. C. albicans, the most common etiologic agent in candidiasis (8Casadevall A. Cassone A. Bistoni F. Cutler J.E. Magliani W. Murphy J.W. Polonelli L. Romani L. Med. Mycol. 1998; 36: 95-105PubMed Google Scholar), commonly affects immunocompromised patients and those undergoing long term antibiotic treatment (9Beck-SagueÌ C.M. Jarvis W.R. J. Infect. Dis. 1993; 167: 1247-1251Crossref PubMed Scopus (1129) Google Scholar). The number of cases of systemic candidiasis has become a major medical problem in hospitals, whereC. albicans is now responsible for up to 25% of nosocomial infections (9Beck-SagueÌ C.M. Jarvis W.R. J. Infect. Dis. 1993; 167: 1247-1251Crossref PubMed Scopus (1129) Google Scholar). Treatment of these infections is becoming increasingly difficult due to increased drug resistance against known antifungal compounds (10Odds F.C. Int. J. Antimicrob. Agents. 1996; 6: 145-147Crossref PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar). Humoral and cell-mediated immunity may both play a major role in host defenses against C. albicans. Whereas most patients with serious mucosal infections have defects in their cellular immunity (11Levitz S.M. Clin. Infect. Dis. 1992; 14: 37-42Crossref PubMed Scopus (122) Google Scholar), patients with deep tissue invasion seem to lack antibodies against the (1â2)-Î²-mannan oligomer found in the yeast cell wall (12Jouault T. Delaunoy C. Sendid B. Ajana F. Poulain D. Clin. Diagn. Lab. Immunol. 1997; 4: 328-333Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Monoclonal antibodies raised against C. albicans cell wall extracts in mice were protective against disseminated candidiasis and vaginal candidiasis (1Han Y. Cutler J.E. Infect. Immun. 1995; 63: 2714-2719Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 2Han Y. Cutler J.E. J. Infect. Dis. 1997; 175: 1169-1175Crossref PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar, 3Han Y. Riesselman M.H. Cutler J.E. Infect. Immun. 2000; 68: 1649-1654Crossref PubMed Scopus (151) Google Scholar, 13Han Y. Kozel T.R. Zhang M.X. MacGill R.S. Carroll M.C. Cutler J.E. J. Immunol. 2001; 167: 1550-1557Crossref PubMed Scopus (130) Google Scholar). Further studies on these protective monoclonal antibodies indicated the active antigen to be a (1â2)-Î²-mannan polymer that is present as a component of the cell wall phosphomannan (14Han Y. Kanbe T. Cherniak R. Cutler J.E. Infect. Immun. 1997; 65: 4100-4107Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) and separately as a phospholipomannan (15Trinel P.-A. Plancke Y. Gerold P. Jouault T. Delplace F. Shwarz R.T. Strecker G. Poulain D. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 30520-30526Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar). In both forms the (1â2)-Î²-mannan antigen is relatively small consisting of between 2 and 14 residues (16Trinel P.A. Lepage G. Joulault T. Strecker G. Poulain D. FEBS Lett. 1997; 416: 203-206Crossref PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar). The immunochemistry and solution properties of this antigen are of great interest because (1â2)-Î²-mannan oligomers have potential as the key epitope of conjugate vaccines (17Han Y. Melinda A. Cutler J.E. J. Infect. Dis. 1999; 179: 1477-1484Crossref PubMed Scopus (139) Google Scholar). Computational studies predicted that homopolysaccharides with this linkage pattern would be of rare occurrence and should exhibit a crumpled conformation to alleviate steric contacts between remote residues (18Rees D.A. Scott W.E. J. Chem. Soc. 1971; : 469-479Google Scholar). To investigate their solution structure and immunochemical properties, a series of short oligomers ranging from di- to hexasaccharides have been synthesized as glycosides and glycoconjugates (Fig. 1) (19Nitz M. Bundle D.R. J. Org. Chem. 2001; 66: 8411-8423Crossref PubMed Scopus (78) Google Scholar, 20Nitz M. Bundle D.R. Org. Lett. 2000; 2: 2939-2942Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). Here the simple glycosides are used to develop a conformational model of the oligosaccharides and to probe the immunochemistry of Î²-mannan-specific monoclonal antibodies that protect mice against C. albicans. Oligosaccharides 1â6 (Fig. 1) and their corresponding conjugates with bovine serum albumin were synthesized as reported elsewhere (19Nitz M. Bundle D.R. J. Org. Chem. 2001; 66: 8411-8423Crossref PubMed Scopus (78) Google Scholar, 20Nitz M. Bundle D.R. Org. Lett. 2000; 2: 2939-2942Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). The monoclonal antibodies, mAb B6.1 (IgM) and mAb C3.1 (IgG3), produced as concentrated tissue culture supernatants and diluted â¼1:40,000 (B6.1) and â¼1:2000 (C3.1) for ELISA1measurements have been described previously (1Han Y. Cutler J.E. Infect. Immun. 1995; 63: 2714-2719Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 2Han Y. Cutler J.E. J. Infect. Dis. 1997; 175: 1169-1175Crossref PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar, 3Han Y. Riesselman M.H. Cutler J.E. Infect. Immun. 2000; 68: 1649-1654Crossref PubMed Scopus (151) Google Scholar, 13Han Y. Kozel T.R. Zhang M.X. MacGill R.S. Carroll M.C. Cutler J.E. J. Immunol. 2001; 167: 1550-1557Crossref PubMed Scopus (130) Google Scholar). C. albicans mannan (22Kanbe T. Han Y. Redgrave B. Riesselman M.H. Cutler J.E. Infect. Immun. 1993; 61: 2578-2584Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) obtained by 2-mercaptoethanol extraction of whole cells without subsequent affinity fractionation was dissolved in PBS (10 Î¼g/ml), and the solution was used to coat 96-well ELISA plates (100 Î¼l, 18 h at 4 Â°C). The plate was washed five times with PBST (PBS containing Tween 20, 0.05% v/v) and blocked for 1 h at room temperature (2% bovine serum albumin/PBS, 100 Î¼l). The monoclonal antibodies were mixed with inhibitor dissolved in PBST at concentrations between 0.1 Î¼m and 1 mm, and the resulting solutions were added to the coated microtiter plate in triplicate and incubated at room temperature for 18 h. The plate was washed with PBST (5 times), and goat anti-mouse (IgG or IgM) antibody conjugated to horseradish peroxidase (diluted 1:2000, Kirkegaard & Perry Laboratories) in PBST (100 Î¼l) was added and incubated for 1 h at room temperature. The plate was washed with PBST (5 times); 3,3â²,5,5â²-tetramethylbenzidine (100 Î¼l, Kirkegaard & Perry Laboratories) was added, and after 2 min the color reaction was stopped by the addition of 1 m phosphoric acid (100 Î¼l). Absorbance was read at 450 nm, and percent inhibition was calculated relative to wells containing antibody without inhibitor. Experiments were carried out on Varian Inova 600- and 800-MHz spectrometers using indirect detection, 5-mm triple resonance, z-gradient probes. Experimental conditions were kept as similar as possible between the two spectrometers, except for inherent field-related differences, and are described here for the 800-MHz data. The sample temperature was 25 Â°C for compounds1â3 and 30 Â°C for compounds 4 and5. The higher temperature moved the HOD peak upfield from the anomeric signals. For data acquisition and processing VNMR 6.1B software was used. Proton chemical shifts were measured relative to external 0.1% acetone at 2.225 ppm. GCOSY and GTOCSY experiments were record as described earlier (23Hurd R.E. J. Magn. Reson. 1990; 87: 422-428Google Scholar, 24Otter A. Hindsgaul O. Bundle D.R. Carbohydr. Res. 1995; 275: 381-389Crossref PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar), the latter with a mixing time of 130 ms at a spin-lock field strength of 6.6 kHz. One scan for each of the 512 t1 incrementations was recorded with a sweep width of 3700 Hz (4.6 ppm), digitized over 4300 data points. Transmitter-based solvent presaturation was used during a 1.5-s relaxation delay, and the acquisition time was 0.6 s. Acquisition parameters for T-ROESY experiments (25Hwang T.-L. Shanka A.J. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1992; 114: 3157-3159Crossref Scopus (325) Google Scholar) were essentially the same as the ones described for the GTOCSY, except that 24 transients were recorded with a total relaxation time of 2.1 s and a mixing time of 400 ms at a spin-lock field of 4.2 kHz. The first two data points in F2 were back-predicted by linear prediction, and no further base-line corrections were applied (26Babcook D.M. Sahasrabudhe P.V. Gmeiner W.H. Magn. Reson. Chem. 1996; 34: 851-857Crossref Scopus (10) Google Scholar). Correlations of interest were checked carefully for undesired TOCSY contributions and integrated on both sides of the diagonal. To obtain a suitable internal reference, the H1âH5 NOEs of each mannopyranose ring were integrated on each side of the diagonal and averaged, and the resulting value was set to 2.39 â« based on the distance found in relevant crystal structures (27Jeffrey G.A. McMullan R.K. Takagi S. Acta Crystallogr. Sect. B Struct. Sci. 1977; 33: 728-737Crossref Google Scholar). Unknown inter-proton distances were then calculated based on the usual râ6 NOE-distance relationship. Some overlapping volumes could only be determined based on the known relative intensities of multiplets that were partially overlapped (an example is shown in Fig.2D). Computer models were developed using the Insight II molecular modeling package (version 2.9.5 from Molecular Simulations Inc.) running on a Silicon Graphics Indigo II computer. All energy calculations were carried out in vacuo with a dielectric constant of 80.0 using the AMBER-plus force field with exo-anomeric potentials (28Homans S.W. Biochemistry. 1990; 29: 9110-9118Crossref PubMed Scopus (379) Google Scholar). To locate a consensus minimum energy conformation, an unrestrained simulated annealing protocol was used (29Rutherford T.J. Spackman D.G. Simpson P.J. Homans S.W. Glycobiology. 1994; 4: 59-68Crossref PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar). In brief, a high temperature-simulated annealing run generated 10 random energy structures. The ring geometries were enforced by scaling the ring torsional energy terms by 7. These structures were then separately cooled in 50 K steps, and at each step a 1-ps molecular dynamics was performed from 500 to 300 K and then to 10 K in 10 K per 1-ps steps and finally to 5 K. Each annealed structure was then minimized using a steepest descent algorithm. The lowest energy structure was used for a 5-ns molecular dynamics run at 300 K. Theoretical time-averaged 1Hâ1H (<râ6>) distances were then calculated using MDPROCESS software. 2T. J. Rutherford, unpublished software. Tri- to pentasaccharides 2â4 and the thio-linked tetrasaccharide 6 were modeled as outlined above. Details for modeling the pentasaccharide 4 are provided below, whereas further details related to the other structures 1â3and 6 are available in the Supplemental Material. Unambiguous 1H and13C chemical shifts for oligosaccharides 1â6were established by a combination of GCOSY, GTOCSY, and HMQC experiments. The most remarkable observation considering the homo-polymeric nature of oligosaccharides 1â5 was the discrete signal dispersion in their 1H NMR spectra (Fig.2A). The excellent dispersion of 1H signals permits the spin system of each hexose residue of the homo-oligomers to be assigned (Fig. 2, A and B). Hemiacetals present in the isolated oligomers cause chemical shift differences and considerable spectral complexity, because both Î± and Î² forms of the terminal residue exist and propagate chemical shift changes well beyond the terminal reducing hexose residue (30Shibata N. Hisamichi K. Kobayashi H. Suzuki S. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1993; 302: 113-117Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar, 31Faille C. Wieruszeski J.-M. Michalski J.-C. Poulain D. Strecker G. Synthetic oligomers by comparison are free of this complicating factor, because the terminal mannose residue is protected as a Î²-propyl glycoside. NOE correlations between protons on either side of each glycosidic linkage established the residue identity of the spin systems of adjacent pyranose rings and confirmed their sequence within each linear oligomer. NOEs were measured from T-ROESY spectra of the oligomers (1â5) and revealed numerous contacts between non-contiguous residues, as illustrated for pentasaccharide 4 (Fig.3). The presence of contacts betweenn + 2 and n + 3 residues is clearly evident in Fig. 2D. All of the anticipated strong NOEs due to inter-glycosidic contacts between H-1 and H-2 of adjacent residues were present and easily quantified due to the signal dispersion of the H-1 and H-2 protons. The T-ROESY cross-peak volumes were quantified for the tri-, tetra-, and pentasaccharide (2â4) and for the thio-linked tetrasaccharide 6. These data were used to derive conformationally averaged inter-proton distances (TableII). Hexasaccharide 5exhibited spectral overlap of several important resonances, and the ROE contacts from this structure were not quantified. Similar distances observed across the glycosidic linkages of the oligomers1â4 and 6 are indicative of compact, repetitive solution structures. The distances also suggest the inferred structure is not just a result of steric interactions between distant, non-contiguous residues but represent a population of low energy conformations with similar torsional angles about the glycosidic linkages. Comparison of the 10 structures of the pentasaccharide obtained from the simulated annealing protocol showed a single family of low energy conformations (Fig. 4A). The excellent signal dispersion observed for the proton resonances of the (1â2)-Î²-mannopyranan oligomers 1â5 suggests they are conformationally distinct, in contrast to other homo-oligomers such as (1â2)-Î±-mannopyranotetrose (38Ogawa T. Yamamoto H. Carbohydr. Res. 1982; 104: 271-283Crossref Scopus (48) Google Scholar) or maltoheptose ((1â4)-Î±-glucopyranoheptose) (39Sugiyama H. Toyohiko N. Horii M. Motohashi K. Sakai J. Usui T. Hisamichi K. Ishiyama J. Carbohydr. Res. 2000; 325: 177-182Crossref PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar), where the conformationally sensitive H-1 resonances have similar chemical shifts. Most homopolysaccharides exhibit this degeneracy in chemical shift (40Caroff M. Bundle D.R. Perry M.B. Cherwonogrodzky J.W. Duncan J.R. Infect. Immun. 1984; 46: 384-388Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 41Kihlberg J. Bundle D.R. Carbohydr. Res. 1991; 216: 67-78Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar), because internal residues sample virtually identical chemical environments. The distinct 1H chemical shifts observed for the H-1 and H-2 resonances of each mannose residue of tetrasaccharide3 suggest that oligomeric (1â2)-Î²-mannopyranans are conformationally distinct in contrast to many homo-oligomers. Similar exceptions occur for both the Î±- and Î²-1,2-linked oligomers of glucose (42Ogawa T. Takanashi Y. Carbohydr. Res. 1983; 123: C16-C18Crossref Scopus (5) Google Scholar, 43Pozsgay V. Robbins J.B. Carbohydr. Res. 1995; 277: 51-66Crossref PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar). These two examples and the (1â2)-Î²-mannopyranan were identified by modeling studies as belonging to a class of homopolymers that would be expected to form relatively stiff and crumpled conformations (18Rees D.A. Scott W.E. J. Chem. Soc. 1971; : 469-479Google Scholar). Chemical shift characteristics of oligomers isolated from C. albicans cell walls have been noted and tentatively interpreted in terms of a collapsed conformation (44Shibata N. Hisamichi K. Kikuchi T. Kobayashi H. Okawa Y. Suzuki S. Biochemistry. 1992; 31: 5680-5686Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar). The use of NOEs to define solution conformations of oligosaccharides is most effective when there are numerous NOEs between hexose residues. This occurs for well defined oligosaccharide conformations that most often result from branching through vicinal substitution, as is the case with the blood group A and B antigens. In this and other such structures (45Otter A. Lemieux R.U. Ball R.G. Venot A.P. Hindsgaul O. Bundle D.R. Eur. J. Biochem. 1999; 259: 295-303Crossref PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar, 46Lemieux R.U. Bock K. Delbaere L.T.J. Koto S. Rao V.S. Can. J. Chem. 1980; 58: 631-653Crossref Google Scholar, 47Bock K. Meldal M. Bundle D.R. Iversen T. Pinto B.M. Garegg P.J. KvanstroÌm I. Norberg T. Lindberg A.A. Svenson S.B. Carbohydr. Res. 1984; 130: 35-53Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar), NOE contacts between non-contiguous residues (for example n and n + 2) often occur spanning the branched pyranose ring. A linear homopolysaccharide can achieve the equivalent of vicinal substitution only if the hydroxyl group adjacent to the anomeric center is the site for chain extension. For aldohexoses this occurs for 1,2-linkages. However, many 1,2-linked homo-oligomers such as those of the Brucella abortus A antigen yield few if any NOE contacts between non-contiguous residues (48Peters T. Brisson J.-R. Bundle D.R. Can. J. Chem. 1990; 68: 979-988Crossref Scopus (43) Google Scholar). The observation of multiple NOE contacts between non-contiguous residues in the (1â2)-Î²-mannopyranans studied here is exceptional in oligosaccharide conformational analysis. The presence of NOE interactions between residues residues A and D (n ton + 3 contacts) is to our knowledge unprecedented and indicative of a compact structure. Unrestrained molecular dynamics of the mannopyranans generated a discrete model of these unique oligosaccharides, which agreed well with the NOE measurements. A comparison of the conformational space sampled by the oligosaccharides indicates that the tri-, tetra-, and pentasaccharides explore very similar torsional angles across all their linkages. The family of conformations sampled is consistent with a model that imparts helical character to this glycan chain (Fig. 4). The repeating unit is approximately 3 residues long, but due to the inherent flexibility about glycosidic torsional angles, the overlap of residues n and n + 3 is only approximate (Supplemental Material Fig. 5). In this family of conformations, hydroxyls are oriented into solution, and a hydrophobic core is made up of the Î±-faces of the mannose rings. It is of interest to note that after this work was completed a different chemical synthesis of the (1â2)-Î²-mannopyranan oligosaccharides was reported, together with a crystal structure of a tetrasaccharide with attached organic protecting groups (49Crich D. Li H. Yao Q. Wink D.J. Sommer R.D. Rheingold A.L. J. Am Chem. Soc. 2001; 123: 5826-5828Crossref PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar). The gross features of this mol

The Pax gene family encodes DNA-binding proteins that can both activate and repress transcription of specific target genes during embryonic development. Pax proteins are required for pattern formation and cell differentiation in a broad spectrum of developing tissues. Consistent with its expression in the intermediate mesoderm, the optic cup and stalk, and the otic vesicle,Pax2, a member of the Pax2/5/8 subfamily, is essential for the development of the renal epithelia, the optic cup, and the inner ear. In addition to a DNA binding domain, the Pax2 protein contains a carboxyl-terminal transactivation domain rich in serine, threonine, and tyrosine. In this report, we demonstrate that the Pax2 transactivation domain is phosphorylated by the c-Jun N-terminal kinase, but not the ERK1/2 or p38 MAP kinases and that phosphorylation is coincident with increased transactivation of a Pax2-dependent reporter gene. Activation of JNK by either upstream kinase MEKK1 or DLK or by expression of Wnt signaling proteins significantly enhances Pax2 phosphorylation in cells. In vitro kinase assays using immunoprecipitated JNK or constitutively active, recombinant JNK show phosphorylation of GST-Pax2 fusion proteins. In transfected cells, phosphorylation of Pax2 correlates with increased transactivation of a Pax2-dependent reporter gene, suggesting that serine/threonine phosphorylation of the transactivation domain is important for Pax2 activity. Pax2 can form a complex with the JNK scaffolding protein JIP1, and this interaction is enhanced by activation of the JNK signaling module with the upstream kinase DLK. The data demonstrate that Pax2 is a new target for the JNK signaling module and point to a novel mechanism for mediating Pax-dependent transcription regulation. Pax proteins are required for pattern formation and cell differentiation in a broad spectrum of developing tissues. Consistent with its expression in the intermediate mesoderm, the optic cup and stalk, and the otic vesicle,Pax2, a member of the Pax2/5/8 subfamily, is essential for the development of the renal epithelia, the optic cup, and the inner ear. In addition to a DNA binding domain, the Pax2 protein contains a carboxyl-terminal transactivation domain rich in serine, threonine, and tyrosine. In this report, we demonstrate that the Pax2 transactivation domain is phosphorylated by the c-Jun N-terminal kinase, but not the ERK1/2 or p38 MAP kinases and that phosphorylation is coincident with increased transactivation of a Pax2-dependent reporter gene. Activation of JNK by either upstream kinase MEKK1 or DLK or by expression of Wnt signaling proteins significantly enhances Pax2 phosphorylation in cells. In vitro kinase assays using immunoprecipitated JNK or constitutively active, recombinant JNK show phosphorylation of GST-Pax2 fusion proteins. In transfected cells, phosphorylation of Pax2 correlates with increased transactivation of a Pax2-dependent reporter gene, suggesting that serine/threonine phosphorylation of the transactivation domain is important for Pax2 activity. Pax2 can form a complex with the JNK scaffolding protein JIP1, and this interaction is enhanced by activation of the JNK signaling module with the upstream kinase DLK. The data demonstrate that Pax2 is a new target for the JNK signaling module and point to a novel mechanism for mediating Pax-dependent transcription regulation. mitogen-activated protein kinase c-Jun N-terminal kinase/stress-activated protein kinase MAPK kinase MEK kinase chloramphenicol acetyltransferase hemagglutinin The Pax family of genes encodes transcription factors with conserved DNA binding motifs that are required for embryonic development of a variety of tissues in Drosophila, mouse, and humans. In vertebrates, Pax genes can be subdivided into classes based on similar features and embryonic expression patterns (1Noll M. Curr. Opin. Genet. Dev. 1993; 3: 595-605Google Scholar). The Pax2/5/8 subfamily is characterized by an amino-terminal-paired domain, a conserved octapeptide sequence with similarity to the engrailed homology domain (EH-1), and a partial-paired type homeobox. Pax2/5/8 proteins are transcription regulators that bind DNA via the amino-terminal-paired domain, whereas the carboxyl-terminal region is required for transactivation of target genes (2Dorfler P. Busslinger M. EMBO J. 1996; 15: 1971-1982Google Scholar, 3Lechner M.S. Dressler G.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 21088-21093Google Scholar). In mouse and man, the Pax2 gene is essential for the development of the kidneys (4Torres M. Gomez-Pardo E. Dressler G.R. Gruss P. Development. 1995; 121: 4057-4065Google Scholar), optic cup, and inner ear (5Torres M. Gomez-Pardo E. Gruss P. Development. 1996; 122: 3381-3391Google Scholar).Pax2 encodes at least two alternatively spliced messages that produce proteins of 392 and 415 amino acids, differing only by a 23 amino acid insertion (6Dressler G.R. Douglass E.C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. (U. S. A.). 1992; 89: 1179-1183Google Scholar). Genes known to be up-regulated by Pax2 include WT1 (7Dehbi M. Ghahremani M. Lechner M. Dressler G. Pelletier J. Oncogene. 1996; 13: 447-453Google Scholar) and gdnf (8Brophy P.D. Ostrom L. Lang K.M. Dressler G.R. Development. 2001; 128: 4747-4756Google Scholar) in the developing kidney and engrailed-2 (9Song D.L. Chalepakis G. Gruss P. Joyner A.L. Development. 1996; 122: 627-635Google Scholar) in the developing hindbrain. In transfected cells, transcription activation requires the Pax2 carboxyl-terminal domain that is rich in serine and threonine residues, which may be potential sites for phosphorylation. In the zebrafish Pax6 protein, the carboxyl-terminal transactivation domain is phosphorylated at multiple serine residues by the mitogen-activated protein kinases (MAPK)1 p38 MAPK and ERK1/2 to increase the transactivation potential (10Mikkola I. Bruun J.A. Bjorkoy G. Holm T. Johansen T. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 15115-15126Google Scholar). Of the Pax2/5/8 subfamily, only Pax8 has been studied with respect to phosphorylation, though it is not clear which kinases are involved (11Poleev A. Okladnova O. Musti A.M. Schneider S. Royer-Pokora B. Plachov D. Eur. J. Biochem. 1997; 247: 860-869Google Scholar). MAP kinase cascades are involved in transmitting signals generated at the cell surface into the cytosol and nucleus and consist of three sequentially acting enzymes: a MAP kinase, an upstream MAP kinase kinase (MEK), and a MEK kinase (MEKK) (12Chang L. Karin M. Nature. 2001; 410: 37-40Google Scholar, 13Davis R.J. Cell. 2000; 103: 239-252Google Scholar). The extracellular signal-regulated kinase 1/2 (ERK 1/2), the c-Jun N-terminal kinase/stress-activated protein kinases (JNK/SAPK), or the p38MAP kinases, can translocate to the nucleus and subsequentely phosphorylate a variety of transcription factors. MEKK1 phosphorylates MKK4/MKK7 to activate JNK but can also activate ERK and p38 MAPK in transfected cells. This report addresses the phosphorylation state of the Pax2 protein and its ability to activate transcription. We show that the carboxyl-terminal activation domain is phosphorylated at serine and threonine residues and that Pax2 phosphorylation is coincident with the enhanced ability to transactivate a reporter gene. Pax2 is a substrate for the c-Jun N-terminal kinase (JNK) but, unlike Pax6, is not phosphorylated by ERK or p38 MAPK. Activation of JNK by either the upstream kinases MEKK1 or DLK or by expression of Wnt signaling proteins increases Pax2 phosphorylation and enhances the Pax2 transactivation potential. The data point to an important role for JNK in modifying the Pax2 transactivation domain and stimulating Pax2-dependent gene expression. The activation domain of Pax2 contains multiple serine, threonine, and tyrosine residues that could serve as potential phosphorylation sites. To determine the status of Pax2 phosphorylation, cells were transfected with epitope-tagged Pax2 and labeled with [32P]orthophosphate. Immunoprecipitation of Pax2 revealed one major form of phosphorylated protein (Fig.1A) and at least one minor form of slightly higher molecular mass. The phospho-Pax2 was excised from the gel and subjected to acid hydrolysis (Fig. 1B). Amino acids were separated by thin layer chromatography using phosphotyrosine, -serine, and -threonine markers and subjected to autoradiography. The immunoprecipitated Pax2 protein was phosphorylated at both serine and threonine residues, but not at tyrosine residues. Given the serine/threonine phosphorylation pattern and previously published reports on Pax6 phosphorylation, we examined the ability of the three major MAP kinases to phosphorylate Pax2 (Fig.2). Cells were transfected with epitope-tagged forms of ERK1, JNK, and p38 MAP kinases and the upstream activator MEKK1. The kinases were immunoprecipitated and used for immunocomplex kinase assays with GST-Pax2 and control substrates. Transfected MEKK1 can activate all three pathways in 293 cells, as demonstrated by increased phosphorylation of ERK, JNK, and p38 in total cell lysates (Fig. 2A). However of the immunoprecipitated kinases, only JNK was able to efficiently phosphorylate GST-Pax2 (Fig.2B). The ability of activated JNK to phosphorylate Pax2 was confirmed using a recombinant, constitutively active form of JNK1 (Fig.2C). The in vitro kinase assay using recombinant JNK and the GST fusion proteins as substrates indicated that GST-Pax2 was as efficient a substrate as GST-c-Jun (Fig. 2C).In vitro phosphorylation of GST-Pax2 was also done with an excess of cold ATP, and the proteins were detected by Western blotting (Fig. 2D). Using anti-Pax2 antibodies, a slower migrating form of the GST-Pax2 fusion protein is observed upon phosphorylation with recombinant JNK. Thus, the antibodies can distinguish between the unphosphorylated and phosphorylated forms of the GST-Pax2 fusion protein.Figure 2Pax2 is a substrate for JNK. 293 cells were transfected with either 0.5 Î¼g of Myc-ERK, FLAG-JNK, or Myc-p38 MAPK expression plasmids, with (+) or without (â) 0.1 Î¼g of MEKK1.A, fraction of the total lysates were analyzed by SDS-PAGE for activation of MAPK by antibodies against P-ERK1/2, P-JNK, and P-p38 as indicated. To map the domain of phosphorylation more precisely, carboxyl-terminal deletion constructs of Pax2b were utilized (Fig. 3). Specific antibodies recognize the 392-amino acid Pax2b protein, which migrates at â¼48 kDa. Upon co-transfection with MEKK1, a slower migrating Pax2b species was observed at â¼50 kDa in SDS-PAGE gels (Fig. 3B). Preincubation of the lysates with either calf intestinal phosphatase or potato acid phosphatase eliminates this slower migrating Pax2b form, indicating that the shift in mobility is due to phosphorylation, similar to what was observed in the in vitro assay (Fig.2D). The MEKK1-dependent, phosphorylated Pax2b form is seen with carboxyl-terminal deletion constructs 1â373, 1â333, but not with deletions that contain only amino acids 1â279. Thus, Pax2b phosphorylation is primarily within the carboxyl-terminal transactivation domain spanning amino acids 279â415. However, phosphorylation at additional sites between amino acids 1â279 that might not affect the mobility of Pax2 in SDS-PAGE gels cannot be ruled out. Strikingly, this region contains 19 serine and 11 threonine residues, making definitive assignment of the phosphorylation sites difficult. During kidney and neural development, Wnt signaling is known to mediate inductive interactions. While the canonical Wnt signaling pathway activates the TCF/LEF family of transcription factors by inhibition of the GSK3 kinase and translocation of Î²-catenin to the nucleus, alternate Wnt signaling pathways can work through the activation of JNK (16Miller J.R. Hocking A.M. Brown J.D. Moon R.T. Oncogene. 1999; 18: 7860-7872Google Scholar, 17Wodarz A. Nusse R. Annu. Rev. Cell Dev. Biol. 1998; 14: 59-88Google Scholar). Particularly during the specification of planar cell polarity (18Mlodzik M. EMBO J. 1999; 18: 6873-6879Google Scholar), activation of JNK is known to require Disheveled and is uncoupled from the TCF/LEF pathway (19Boutros M. Mlodzik M. Mech. Dev. 1999; 83: 27-37Google Scholar, 20Moriguchi T. Kawachi K. Kamakura S. Masuyama N. Yamanaka H. Matsumoto K. Kikuchi A. Nishida E. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 30957-30962Google Scholar, 21Li L. Yuan H. Xie W. Mao J. Caruso A.M. McMahon A. Sussman D.J. Wu D. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 129-134Google Scholar). Given the relationship between Wnt signaling, kidney development, and JNK activation, we examined the ability of Wnt proteins to activate JNK and stimulate Pax2 phosphorylation. Cells were co-transfected with expression plasmids for Wnt4, Wnt11, and Wnt7a and examined for JNK activation and Pax2 phosphorylation (Fig. 4A). Analysis of total lysates from 293 cells co-transfected with Wnt expression vectors and Pax2b indicated co-incident phosphorylation of Pax2, as evidenced by the slower migrating Pax2b isoform (Fig.4A). Activation of the Wnt pathway results in the slower migration of the disheveled protein, through phosphorylation at multiple sites, as reported previously (22Rothbacher U. Laurent M.N. Deardorff M.A. Klein P.S. Cho K.W. Fraser S.E. EMBO J. 2000; 19: 1010-1022Google Scholar, 23Lee J.S. Ishimoto A. Yanagawa S. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 21464-21470Google Scholar). Cells transfected with each of the three Wnt constructs also exhibited co-incident activation of JNK (Fig. 4A). The phosphorylation of Pax2 was confirmed by in vivo labeling with [32P]orthophosphate (Fig. 4B). MEKK1 co-transfected cells showed high levels of phospho-Pax2, whereas Wnt11 co-transfected cells showed less phospho-Pax2 but significantly more than cells expressing Pax2 alone. The data indicate that activation of JNK by either Wnt proteins or MEKK1 results in increased phosphorylation of Pax2. Activation of the JNK pathway can also occur with via the mixed lineage kinases (MLK or DLK) in association with the scaffolding proteins of the JIP family (14Nihalani D. Meyer D. Pajni S. Holzman L.B. EMBO J. 2001; 20: 3447-3459Google Scholar, 24Yasuda J. Whitmarsh A.J. Cavanagh J. Sharma M. Davis R.J. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 7245-7254Google Scholar, 25Whitmarsh A.J. Cavanagh J. Tournier C. Yasuda J. Davis R.J. Science. 1998; 281: 1671-1674Google Scholar). To determine whether Pax2 interacts directly with this JNK signaling module, cells were co-transfected with Pax2, JIP1, DLK, and JNK (Fig. 5). Expression of DLK alone slightly increased the amount of phospho-Pax2 present in total lysates. At low doses of DLK, Pax2 phosphorylation was further enhanced by co-expression with JIP1 or JNK. Immunoprecipitation of JIP1 also pulled down Pax2 and JNK, indicating that at least some Pax2 was associated with the JNK signaling module. Strikingly, Pax2 could be co-immunoprecipitated with JIP1 in the absence of DLK, but the amount of JIP1-associated Pax2 increased significantly upon activation of the JNK module with DLK. More phosphorylated Pax2 was observed by expression of DLK, together with exogenous JNK, and this resulted in even more JIP1-associated Pax2. In the absence of exogenous JIP1, co-transfection of DLK and JNK produced even more phosphorylated Pax2. At first this may seem counterintuitive, but transfection of exogenous JIP1 provides more scaffolding such that individual proteins may not all assemble on the same scaffold and thus effectively titrate out some of the activities (14Nihalani D. Meyer D. Pajni S. Holzman L.B. EMBO J. 2001; 20: 3447-3459Google Scholar). The data suggest that DLK-dependent phosphorylation of Pax2 by JNK is mediated by a direct association with the JNK signaling module, perhaps through interactions with JIP1. To assess the effects of Pax2 phosphorylation on the transactivation potential, we utilized a reporter plasmid containing five copies of the PRS4 Pax2b binding sequence upstream of a minimal promoter and the chloramphenicol acetyltransferase (CAT) gene. Using a fixed amount of Pax2b plasmid (125 ng) and increasing amounts of MEKK1, Pax2-dependent reporter activation increased dramatically with as little as 50 ng of MEKK1 expression plasmid (Fig.6A). Pax2 transfection can stimulate the reporter plasmid activity by 8â10-fold. This increased to more than 50-fold by co-transfection of 200 ng of MEKK1 expression plasmid. In the absence of Pax2, MEKK1 had no effect on the expression of the reporter. Furthermore, a kinase-deficient MEKK1 construct showed only a slight increase at the highest doses. Pax2-dependent transactivation was also enhanced in the presence of Wnt expression plasmids (Fig. 6B). Expression of Wnt4, Wnt11, and Wnt7a all generated a 2â3-fold increase in Pax2-dependent activation of the reporter gene. Whereas Wnt gene expression alone had no effect on CAT activity in the absence of Pax2 (data not shown). As reported previously (3Lechner M.S. Dressler G.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 21088-21093Google Scholar), deletion of the transactivation domain reduced Pax2-dependent activation (Fig. 6C). A carboxyl-terminal deletion of amino acids 373â415 still showed a robust response to MEKK1 although the basal level of Pax2-dependent activation was down about 2-fold. However, a carboxyl-terminal deletion of amino acids 333â415 exhibited a further reduction in basal activation and a loss of responsiveness to MEKK1. Western blotting indicated that there was some degree of Pax2-(1â333) phosphorylation in response to MEKK1 (Fig. 3B). However, it is unlikely that these remaining phosphorylation sites are necessary for the increased activation potential in response to MEKK1. These data suggest that the critical phosphorylated residues in Pax2 that mediate the MEKK1-induced transcriptional activation are located between amino acids 333 and 415. Similarly, activation of JNK via DLK and JIP increased the transactivation potential of Pax2 (Fig. 6D). DLK and Pax2 alone increased reporter activity only slightly. However, co-transfection of DLK with JIP1 increased the Pax2-dependent transactivation potential by 3â4-fold. Thus in all cases examined, the factors that increase JNK activity and result in increased amounts of Pax2 phosphorylation also significantly enhance the Pax2 dependent transactivation potential of the PRS4 reporter vector. In this report, we demonstrate that Pax2, a member of the Pax family of transcription regulators, is phosphorylated by JNK. Also known as SAPK, JNK phosphorylates a variety of nuclear transcription factors, including c-Jun, Elk1, and ATF2. In particular, phosphorylation of Ser-63 and Ser-73 of c-Jun results in increased activity of the AP-1 transcription factor, which consists of a c-Fos/c-Jun heterodimer (13Davis R.J. Cell. 2000; 103: 239-252Google Scholar). Indeed, the sequence around Ser-63 of c-Jun (LLTSP) is very similar to a conserved serine at position 393 of the Pax2 protein (LLSSP). However, phosphorylation of Pax2 may occur at multiple sites. Deletion of the serine/threonine-rich, carboxyl-terminal transactivation domain significantly reduces phosphorylation such that a shift in Pax2b mobility, upon JNK activation, is no longer observed. The phosphorylated residues that mediate the JNK-dependent increase in transactivation reside between amino acids 333 and 415 of the activation domain. Within this region there are 11 serine and 7 threonine residues, of which 6 and 1 respectively are absolutely conserved within the Pax2/5/8 family. We have begun making point mutations of these conserved residues. However, preliminary data indicate that multiple serine substitution must be made before the MEKK1-dependent increase in transactivation is abrogated (data not shown). By definition, the transactivation domain is required for maximal activation potential of the Pax2 reporter gene, PRS4-CAT, as defined previously in the absence of exogenous JNK activators. A basal level of phospho-Pax2 is present that most probably accounts for the 8â10-fold transactivation potential observed without JNK activation. This basal levels accounts for the metabolically labeled phospho-Pax2 observed without JNK activation and the small amount of high molecular weight Pax2b form observed upon long exposures of Western blots. Basal levels of activated JNK and phospho-c-Jun are inevitably observed in proliferating cells stimulated with serum. Because there are presently no practical JNK inhibtors, we were unable to test whether JNK activation was absolutely required for Pax2-mediated transactivation. However, several lines of evidence indicate that JNK is the kinase responsible for Pax2 phosphorylation, which correlates with increased transactivation. Of the major MAP kinases, only JNK is able to phosphorylate Pax2 in the immunolinked kinase assay. Furthermore, recombinant constitutively active JNK phosphorylates Pax2 in vitro as efficiently as it phosphorylates c-Jun. Increased JNK activity leads to increased Pax2 phosphorylation and increased Pax2-dependent transactivation, regardless of whether JNK is activated by MEKK1, Wnt signaling, or DLK. Pax2 can associate with the JNK signaling module as demonstrated by the co-immunoprecipitation of Pax2 with JIP1. Strikingly, activation of the signaling module by the DLK results in increased JIP1-associated Pax2. A specific inhibitor of MEK1 (PD98059), which suppresses phosphorylation of the ERK1/2 MAPK, does not significantly reduce Pax2 phosphorylation nor does it reduce Pax2-dependent transactivation (data not shown). While JNK is likely to be the kinase that mediates phosphorylation of Pax2, the effect on Pax2 activity is less clear. It remains to be determined whether Pax2 phosphorylation by JNK is merely co-incident with enhanced activation, whether it is a prerequisite for further modification by other kinases, or whether there is indeed a causative link to enhanced Pax2 activation potential. In the developing kidney and central nervous system, Wnt signaling and Pax genes play critical roles in establishing patterns and specifying cell types. During kidney development, Pax2 is expressed in the metanephric mesenchyme prior to induction by the ureteric bud epithelium (8Brophy P.D. Ostrom L. Lang K.M. Dressler G.R. Development. 2001; 128: 4747-4756Google Scholar). Upon induction, Pax2-expressing cells proliferate, aggregate around the tips of the ureteric bud, and undergo conversion to an epithelial phenotype (6Dressler G.R. Douglass E.C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. (U. S. A.). 1992; 89: 1179-1183Google Scholar, 26Ryan G. Steele-Perkins V. Morris J. Rauscher III., F.J. Dressler G.R. Development. 1995; 121: 867-875Google Scholar). This response to inductive signals is Pax2-dependent (4Torres M. Gomez-Pardo E. Dressler G.R. Gruss P. Development. 1995; 121: 4057-4065Google Scholar, 27Rothenpieler U.W. Dressler G.R. Development. 1993; 119: 711-720Google Scholar) and also requires Wnt4 signaling (28Stark K. Vainio S. Vassileva G. McMahon A.P. Nature. 1994; 372: 679-683Google Scholar). That Wnt4 can activate JNK and stimulate Pax2-dependent gene activation suggests that phosphorylation of Pax2 is an essential component of the induction response. Thus, Pax2 may be an immediate downstream target for inductive signals that can translate these signals by initiating the epithelial-specific genetic program. Pax2 and the related genes Pax5 andPax8 are also active during neural development, particularly in the mid-brain/hindbrain junction of the central nervous system (29Pfeffer P.L. Bouchard M. Busslinger M. Development. 2000; 127: 1017-1028Google Scholar, 30Schwarz M. Alvarez-Bolado G. Dressler G. Urbanek P. Busslinger M. Gruss P. Mech. Dev. 1999; 82: 29-39Google Scholar, 31Bouchard M. Pfeffer P. Busslinger M. Development. 2000; 127: 3703-3713Google Scholar). Mice carrying targeted mutations for both JNK1 and JNK2 show regional defects in the developing hindbrain, including decreased apoptosis prior to neural tube closure in and around the Pax2/5/8 expression domain (32Kuan C.Y. Yang D.D. Samanta Roy D.R. Davis R.J. Rakic P. Flavell R.A. Neuron. 1999; 22: 667-676Google Scholar). Thus, modulation of Pax activity by JNK may also be required for the regulation of neuronal cell number through selective activation of apoptosis. In any event, more direct studies in normal and mutant mice are warranted to more precisely determine the phosphorylation state of Pax proteins during specific stages of development. We thank A. McMahon for the Wnt4 cDNA, R. Nusse for the Dvl antibodies, B. Zhang for reagents and advice, B. Margolis for JIP1 and comments on the manuscript, and I. Levitan for technical assistance.

Salmonella survive and replicate within mammalian cells by becoming secluded within specialized membrane-bound vacuoles inaccessible to the host defense mechanisms. Delayed acidification of the vacuole and its incomplete fusion with lysosomes have been implicated in intracellularSalmonella survival. Nramp1 confers to macrophages resistance to a variety of intracellular pathogens, including Salmonella, but its precise mode of action is not understood. We investigated whether Nramp1 affects the maturation and acidification of Salmonella-containing vacuoles (SCV). A mouse-derived macrophage line (RAW/Nramp1â) devoid of Nramp1 and therefore susceptible to infection was compared with isogenic clones stably transfected with Nramp1(RAW/Nramp1+). Intravacuolar pH, measuredin situ, was similar in Nramp1-expressing and -deficient cells. SCV acquired LAMP1 and fused with preloaded fluid-phase markers in both cell types. In contrast, although few vacuoles in RAW/Nramp1â acquired mannose 6-phosphate receptor, many more contained M6PR in RAW/Nramp1+ cells. Shortly after closure, SCV in RAW/Nramp1â became inaccessible to extracellular markers, suggesting inability to fuse with newly formed endosomes. Expression of Nramp1 markedly increased the access to extracellularly added markers. We propose that Nramp1 counteracts the ability of Salmonella to become secluded in a compartment that limits access of bactericidal agents, allowing the normal degradative pathway of the macrophage to proceed. Salmonella-containing vacuole natural-resistance-associated macrophage protein 1 lipopolysaccharide phosphate-buffered saline fluorescein isothiocyanate green fluorescent protein mannose 6-phosphate receptor Salmonella species cause systemic diseases including typhoid fever and gastroenteritis in humans and other animals (1Pang T. Bhutta Z.A. Finlay B.B. Altwegg M. Trends Microbiol. 1995; 3: 253Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (153) Google Scholar). These bacteria are intracellular pathogens, capable of invading the host cells where they reside in spacious vacuoles. Five pathogenicity islands have been identified to encode the factors required forSalmonella invasion and replication. SPI-1 (forSalmonella pathogenicity island-1) encodes a complex bacterial type III secretion system, which mediates bacterial uptake (invasion) into host cells (2Collazo C.M. Zierler M.K. Galan J.E. Mol. Microbiol. 1995; 15: 25-38Crossref PubMed Scopus (118) Google Scholar). SPI-2 encodes a second type III secretion system that becomes active only after the bacteria reach the intracellular vacuole. SPI-2 generates factors required for intracellular survival and replication of Salmonella and is critical for virulence (3Ochman H. Soncini F.C. Solomon F. Groisman E.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 7800-7804Crossref PubMed Scopus (530) Google Scholar, 4Shea J.E. Hensel M. Gleeson C. Holden D.W. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 2593-2597Crossref PubMed Scopus (646) Google Scholar, 5Cirillo D.M. Valdivia R.H. Monack D.M. Falkow S. Mol. Microbiol. 1998; 30: 175-188Crossref PubMed Scopus (481) Google Scholar, 6Hensel M. Shea J.E. Waterman S.R. Mundy R. Nikolaus T. Banks G. Mol. Microbiol. 1998; 30: 163-174Crossref PubMed Scopus (500) Google Scholar). Finally, three small pathogenicity islands, SPI-3, SPI-4, and SPI-5, encode additional effectors and themgtC operon, which allows Salmonella typhimuriumto survive in low Mg2+ conditions (7Blanc-Potard A.B. Groisman E.A. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 5376-5385Crossref PubMed Scopus (272) Google Scholar, 8Hong K.H. Miller V.L. J. Bacteriol. 1998; 180: 1793-1802Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 9Hardt W.D. Chen L.M. Shuebel K.E. Bustelo X.R. Galan J.E. Cell. 1998; 93: 815-826Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (668) Google Scholar, 10Pfeifer C.G. Marcus S.L. Steele-Mortimer O. Knodler L.A. Finlay B.B. Infect. Immun. 1999; 67: 5690-5698Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Infectious organisms are generally eliminated from the host, at least in part, by the innate immune system. Phagocytes ingest the microorganisms into a membrane-bound compartment or phagosome, which matures by sequential fusion with a series of endomembrane compartments (11Desjardins M. Huber L.A. Parton R.G. Griffiths G. J. Cell Biol. 1994; 124: 677-688Crossref PubMed Scopus (561) Google Scholar). The resulting changes in the composition and luminal pH confer to the phagosome its characteristic microbicidal properties. To survive intracellularly, Salmonella evades the hostile environment of the phagosome by subverting the maturation process. Instead of undergoing the customary fusion with the endosomal and lysosomal compartments, yielding a phagolysosome, Salmonella generates a unique compartment denominated the Salmonella-containing vacuole (SCV)1 that ultimately segregates itself from the endocytic pathway (12Garcia del Portillo F. Finlay B.B. J. Cell Biol. 1995; 129: 81-97Crossref PubMed Scopus (209) Google Scholar). Survival of bacteria within the SCV has been attributed to the incomplete fusion of the latter with the pre-lysosomal and lysosomal compartments (12Garcia del Portillo F. Finlay B.B. J. Cell Biol. 1995; 129: 81-97Crossref PubMed Scopus (209) Google Scholar,13Rathman M. Barker L.P. Falkow S. Infect. Immun. 1997; 65: 1475-1485Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), which is accompanied by delayed and/or reduced luminal acidification (14Alpuche-Aranda C.M. Swanson J.A. Loomis W.P. Miller S.I. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 10079-10083Crossref PubMed Scopus (362) Google Scholar). Not all individuals are equally susceptible to Salmonellainfection. This is attributed in some instances to the expression of host gene products that confer natural resistance to the bacteria (15Vidal S.M. Malo D. Vogan K. Skamene E. Gros P. Cell. 1993; 73: 469-485Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (989) Google Scholar, 16Vidal S.M. Tremblay M.L. Govoni G. Gauthier S. Sebastiani G. Malo D. Skamene E. Olivier M. Jothy S. Gros P. J. Exp. Med. 1995; 182: 655-666Crossref PubMed Scopus (506) Google Scholar, 17Vidal S.M. Gros P. Skamene E. J. Leukocyte Biol. 1995; 58: 382-390Crossref PubMed Scopus (132) Google Scholar). One such resistance factor is natural resistance-associated macrophage protein 1 (Nramp1), an integral membrane protein expressed in lysosomal compartments of macrophages (18Gruenheid S. Pinner E. Desjardins M. Gros P. J. Exp. Med. 1997; 185: 717-730Crossref PubMed Scopus (391) Google Scholar, 19Searle S. Bright N.A. Roach T.I.A. Atkinson P.G.P. Barton C.H. Meloen R.H. Blackwell J.M. J. Cell Sci. 1998; 111: 2855-2866Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The mechanism whereby Nramp1 confers to the host resistance to infection is incompletely understood. Following phagocytosis, Nramp1 reaches the phagosome membrane (18Gruenheid S. Pinner E. Desjardins M. Gros P. J. Exp. Med. 1997; 185: 717-730Crossref PubMed Scopus (391) Google Scholar), where it has been suggested to prevent the replication of bacteria by limiting the availability of luminal divalent cations (20Govoni G. Gros P. Inflamm. Res. 1998; 47: 277-284Crossref PubMed Scopus (139) Google Scholar, 21Jabado N. Jankowski A. Dougaparsad S. Picard V. Grinstein S. Gros P. J. Exp. Med. 2000; 192: 1237-1248Crossref PubMed Scopus (327) Google Scholar). It is unclear, however, whether and how these putative alterations in divalent cation content modify the ability of the bacteria to evade phagosomal maturation and segregate into a characteristic SCV. The purpose of this study was to determine whether the presence of Nramp1 alters the intracellular fate of Salmonella in cultured and in primary murine macrophages. Maturation of the SCV was monitored using markers of the compartments of the endocytic pathway and measuring intravacuolar pH by digital imaging. Our results suggest that macrophages expressing the Nramp1 protein counteract the ability of Salmonella to become secluded in a compartment that limits access of bactericidal agents. We propose thatNramp1 facilitates bacterial killing by altering the pattern of vacuolar fusion with endomembranes.
